Don't even bother entering the restroom unless you have a gas mask on. When you come to El Farolito, you do it for the cheap and gut-busting Mexican food. Nothing more, nothing less.

ProTip: Let them know if you want to try out multiple types of meats in your burrito. By no means are you constrained to just one. Trust me, there is plenty of room in those massive tortillas.
author: Miko B.

description: Delicious tripe and carnitas tacos! We only ordered one taco each, but the sizes were big enough to fill us up. My boyfriend and I both wish the tortillas had a little more crisp to them. The corn tortillas got a little soggy because of the juices from the carnitas; I guess that really means I should eat faster!  Wish the salsas had a touch more flavor, but truthfully the meat had enough flavor that salsa wasn't really necessary. Would definitely go back and maybe even try one of their super giant burritos!
author: Edith Q.

description: Being from San Diego, I have a soft spot for a good burrito. I was super excited to finally try this place! I got the super burrito with carne Asada! It was a huge burrito! Perfect size for the price. Taking the first bite, I tasted the beans, rice, and sour cream. I didn't get to the meat part yet but it was already amazing! The second bite with the meat was satisfying to say the least! They have three type of sauces from the green sauce (mild), medium salsa, and spicy salsa. I got the spicy salsa and it was a nice kick! I do think the avocado, sour cream and cheese adds a lot of flavor to the super burrito so you don't really need more sauce. I might opt out to the normal burrito without the extra sauce next time. Overall, really good burrito!
author: Ellen V.

description: Dude. This fucking place! Let me start with the positive. The tacos and overall food are perfect for late night Mexican. Love the food. However, I contemplate not coming here anymore because of the guys who take your order. The regular old guy on the weekends....dude I've been coming here for years!!!!! 10 years. You always act like a dismissive butthole!!!! Be nicer, Jesus. The younger guys  if I say "for here" they always wrap it to go and once I tell them they screwed up yet AGAIN  they don't even apologize and ask me if I'd like a plate lol  this staff needs to learn some manners dude. I hate giving them my money because I feel the price and service should match. I'm just saying guys, I've worked in restaurants many years. A little politeness for the people for patronize your establishment costs you nothing.
author: PJ L.

description:
If you're reading this review while in El Farolito's ridiculously long line or are thinking of heading to El Farolito to stand in their ridiculously long line, I highly recommend changing plans and choosing another taqueria. If you're dead set on sampling something from El Farolito (as I was) to see what all the hype and line is about, I suggest walking to their 24th and Alabama St. location. It's a bit of a schlep, but the space is larger and I have heard the line is shorter. If you're too hungry to walk seven short blocks to Alabama St., head south on Mission St. to Taquería La Corneta, one of my favorites in the city, or north on Mission St. to La Taqueria, although they also have a notoriously long line and higher prices.

I went to El Farolito whilst on my Mission district taquería crawl, sampling various veggie tacos, and I was not impressed at all. Even before I bit into the stale tortillas that they used to make my veggie taco, I was turned off by having to pay $0.65 for a side of chips. 9 out 10 taquerias in the Mission include chips with any order. The taco was so-so, but not worth the wait in line or the grubby environs.

My conclusion = El Farolito must be written up in tons of the tourist guides (the place is packed with folks who are clearly not from the area), and is perhaps cruising on a reputation it built a long time ago and has since lost.

I've been to (this location of) El Farolito twice: the first and last time.
author: Beau W.

description: This place is great! The food is really simply awesome - I'd highly recommend the al pastor super burrito. The only issue I have with the place is the environment; it's very loud and super difficult to find a seat. Also bear in mind it's cash only (a bit silly if you ask me in this day and age in San Francisco...), and the ATM outside has an expensive surcharge, so bring cash ahead of time!
author: Jake B.

description: This is an SF institution and it's easy to see why. It brings together folks who love Mexican food. They do it well here too. Cash only. Fast, easy, cheap and delicious. Did you know that a rice-less burrito is basically a super quesadilla (and I don't care for the beans in the burrito). Too bad it smells like piss right outside at the door. Sigh.
author: Alias A.

description:
This is the busiest burrito place on Mission in my time at SF, and I think it's due to the fact that it's on Mission, birthplace of the Mission Burrito known worldwide, but also that it's across the street from the BART station.

After lining up, and disappointing the cashier with my lack of Spanish skills during my order, I waited for my food to arrive.  I had the large size burrito, and it was easily the biggest burrito I've ever eaten.  The biggest differences between Mission Street burritos and burritos I've had back in Canada seem to be the cheese (no cheddar in SF!), and guac (blended instead of mashed in Toronto).  Other than that it comes down to personal preference. 

This is definitely the first place you should try when doing a burrito crawl on Mission, as it sets the bar for what a Mission burrito looks and tastes like.
author: Alex L.

description:
Meh. I've had better burritos than this. They're so busy so it's like they rush to get your food done as quickly as possible. Not trippin but the food is ok. 
Taqueria San Bruno blows them out of the water. Bet me on that!
author: Thien T.

description:
This is the only place I will go for a burrito in San Francisco. Their veggie burrito is amazing, whether you get it super or not. It might be the best veggie burrito I have ever had! My boyfriend says the same about their Al Pastor burrito. 

They have a self-serve salsa bar so you can dress your food how you like. The prices are consistent with the other Mexican places on Mission street. 

It is cash only, so be prepared for that. The environment is definitely no frills.
author: M P.

description:
I came here around 10pm and the line was out the door. It moves quick though. 

They have big ass tacos ! 

The lengua and the tripas is a must have !
author: Allen T.

description: Didn't even put avocado on my super veggie burrito! not worth the wait even after a night of drinking
author: Riley G.

description: Great drunchies!! They do not skimp on the meat and service is pretty fast. The only complaint is the excess amount of homeless people wandering around the area.
author: Jessica K.

description:
I loved the super burrito. Great deal. Perfectly shareable. The service, and the unlimited salsa bar were all huge pluses. But I wasn't impressed with my pastor taco and my ceviche appetizer. As expected, they use bottled lime juice, not the fresh kind, which completely ruins the taste. 

As for the taco, the tortilla was a bit on the dry side and the pastor did not have enough pineapple flavor which I prefer. This probably won't be the best taco you will have

In all, if you order the super burrito, it should definitely be worth the trip, even the long wait, but for me, it was not deserving of the hype. Come with reasonable expectations and you will leave with a happy belly.
author: Christina N.

description:
PLEASE tell me where all the hype for this place is coming from. 

Overhyped and way too dirty of a space to venture out for.

The two stars I'm giving to Farolito go directly to their chips and accompanying salsas-- crispy and delicious (especially the green sauce!) and definitely not foreshadowing of the meal to come.

My fiance, who is a huge Mexican food aficionado ordered himself a chicken burrito and I had a chicken taco and tostada.

The chicken is boiled and has absolutely no flavor (I am grateful for their salsas in being the saving grace). Both the taco and tostada came out extremely wet and were not crunchy as expected. I ate them both because frankly I was starving, but there is no way we'd venture back here... unless offered a large sum of money.

Hard pass.
author: Leena T.

description:
To be honest, if you don't at least LIKE el farolito, I don't know what you are doing with your life. 

This is hands down one of my favorite places in the Bay.

Food: I pretty much ALWAYS get super suiza aka quesadilla with chicken cheese sour cream avocados and salsa and such. It is MUCH bigger than you would think. Almost everytime I go in thinking I am hungry and can finish, but i never do. There is only a minor down side which is occasional and might change depending on order, this last time it was dripping wet. Not sure from what, likely the salsa or something, but it made it difficult to save the other half so i just ate as much as I can. Also the salsa's they have are amazing, so def get some chips you can munch on while you wait. The wait for the food is not very long, and the line is usually moving fairly quickly.

Place: This location is a long narrow store located on mission next to 24th BART. It has probably a good 10 tables of 4. It is definitely always crowded when I go. However, turn over rate on the tables is pretty good and if you wait a little you can probably find seating. If you go alone just share with someone else thats alone!

Price: VERY MUCH WORTH IT


Go, chill, eat, make sure you have an appetite and don't mind grease.
author: Akash P.

description: Delicious but very heavy if you're not used to some serious Mexican food. I would definitely cut down my portion next time but overall really tasty!
author: Diana C.

description: Carne Asada super burrito was the best plus the fresh salsa! This was an easy stop off 24th and Mission Bart. We were in SF for a couple days and we regret not going back to try another item off the menu. The space was as expected (casual and seating was easy to find around 11am on a Monday) and the food was amazingly beyond our expectations. We paid cash based off Yelp recommendations.
author: Jessica F.

description: The el pastor quesadilla was super good but I wasn't a huge fan of the sandwiches. The wait was about 25 minutes at around 2 in the afternoon.  The inside is kind of cheap and dirty but the food is good.
author: Ece K.

description:
really this is the birthplace of the burrito? when you visit a mecca, a birthplace of a particular food you expect it to be amazing and this wasn't even good. ive had worst tasting burritos in LA and SD that would blow farolito out of the water.

what i was expecting carne asada grilled whole then hand chopped, and not hand chopped to submission where their tiny beef got even tinier.  

ill upload a picture of our favorite taco shop (Maritza, SD) and look at their grilled whole carne asada thats hand chopped, and you tell me which one looks mouth watering that you'd drive to no matter how far? 

this would be equivalent to going to Philly and getting cheese steaks and finding out the ones in NY were better. so before you give this place more than 1 star make sure your sober before eating their food cause it taste completely different when you know what your eating.
author: NYSD G.

description:
Terrible dirty place. Got our order wrong and wouldn't even correct it. Didn't retake our order, just waved us off. 

Never returning. Stay away
author: TC C.

description: We arrived around 2 AM and the line was out the door. This place is opened late -- till 3 AM?!! The food is great. They are extra generous with their meats, the price is pretty affordable, and seating is plentiful. The salsas are flavorful but may be pretty spicy so taste before you pile it on.
author: Mee V.

description:
I finally get the hype about West Coast Mexican food; it really is incredible.

I've tried the quesadilla and tacos at this place and they're all fantastic. Make sure to get the super suiza, which comes with sour cream and avocado, and is much heftier than the standard quesadilla.

Huge portions, cheap and delicious! It's a bit of a dive, but that's all part of the atmosphere.
author: Harry X.

description:
Came here this past Labor Day weekend 2017, AKA Hell on Earth 2017. It was the most insane heat wave to hit SF and it really did not help that we hiked Muir Woods before coming here. With that said, you know a restaurant is good when you're literally dripping sweat in between bites in a sauna of a restaurant and you still walk away feeling amazing. 

We tried the regular burrito AND the super burrito. Both were flawless. I'm drooling just thinking about it. SF was definitely not my favorite city, but I'd trek through the ammonia-smelling streets (to put it nicely) and crazy hills just to have another burrito from El Farolito. Come early, order two burritos, and thank yourself later when you get to experience heaven all over again.
author: Priscilla S.

description:
This was my first trip to the US and my awesome friend insisted I try this place while I was in San Francisco. I have never been so grateful for a food recommendation! Even though I was mega jet lagged, off we went at around 12MN to El Farolito!

Two words that come to mind when I was in line: HUGE. PORTIONS. I let my friends do the ordering. They got a super burrito with everything on it plus shrimp. It was UH-Mazing! The meat was so flavorful and I was super impressed that they used actual avocado, not guacamole. The fresh avocado added so much more flavor. The burrito was way too big, it's better to one then share it with like...4 people! Seriously, you can have half for dinner, half for lunch the next day. They also ordered this super quesadilla that was filled so much CHEESE! First time to try real Asadero and Queso Fresco! Sooo goood! The quesadilla was perfectly done; crispy outer layer with good amounts of ingredients in the inside including avocado, sour cream, tomato, onion, cilantro, ALL the cheese, and meat. You will not feel cheated.

From my experience, there will always be a looong line. BUT, that's what happens when the food is very, very delicious! Don't worry, it moves pretty quickly. If you plan to eat here, it is not exactly bright and airy. It is a small and compact place; very cozy authentic cantina (like how I imagined it would be!). Lasty, this is an awesome place for late night "drunk food." I will most definitely be back here if or when I return to San Francisco! :D
author: Joey R.

description: Omgosh. Must have. Eat anything with the Mexican Sausage. This place is so busy. But worth it
author: Lisa K.

description: My favorite burrito place in the Mission, and probably SF... always make it a point to stop here if I'm ever in the city, even if I'm not hungry! I love al pastor (marinated pork), and the way they do it here is... SO... good. My brother loves it when we stand in line and we can see them flipping the different meats with their long, flat spatulas. It's cash only, and there's a little ATM inside the store for those who only carry card. I always get the super burrito because, come on, if that or a normal burrito without sour cream and guac (only a tiny bit cheaper)... You're gonna get the super burrito. Water is self serve, seating is self-seating, and after you order you get a number that they yell out for you to either take to go or sit down and eat. Again, can't stress how much I love this place!!
author: Carol L.

description:
My death row last meal on earth is the super suiza quesadilla with al pastor. New on my list is the super chile relleno burrito. 

This place however is not for the faint of heart. Yesterday a mariachi band came in after some Trump supporter called a homeless (but harmless) loiterer an n-word. Tonight a pigeon made it all the way to the back of the restaurant while cleaning up floored tortilla chips.
author: Clifford K.

description:
This has been my favorite burrito place since 2000!! Super grill chicken with extra avocado and sour cream the Best!!! The Grill chicken is never dry. 

Well I haven't been in a while it was starting to change a little... once I went and ordered a steak and shrimp and didn't get not one shrimp :( but back in the days they could do no wrong best thing popping on 24th & Mission
author: Mychelle T.

description:
Get the shrimp burrito!  A local recommended this place for their huge shrimps and they did not disappoint. They give you so many pieces of shrimp and boy are they flavorful and spicy.  We already had a burrito from la tacqueria but i just could not stop eating this one!
Kinda dirty looking eating areas but the burrito was good!
author: K L.

description: Had the Super Burrito with cabeza and it tasted awesome.  Unfortunately, we got food poisoning a few hours after eating here.  The burrito was so good it was almost worth it.
author: JP M.

description:
Coming to SF, my friend and I had one mission in mind: see what the hype was about for tacos and burritos. We were torn between El Farolito and La Taqueria. But since La Taqueria was closed today on a Monday, we decided to go here.

The wait was around 10 minutes but well worth it! I ordered tacos: the lengua (tongue), carne asada (steak), al pastor (marinated pork). Everything was packed with flavor !
author: Chloe C.

description: Oh, how I love El Farolito! Best burritos in the city! Portions are so generous, the burritos stand up by themselves!  Grab a Philz coffee down the street, pick up a breakfast burrito, and go sit in Delores Park.  A perfect Saturday!
author: Rick R.

description:
True life: I get HANGRY. Maybe more than the normal person should.* I was in this sort of mood and El Farolito was the only answer. Thankfully, that answer was a great one. 

Now, this hood is something else. (As is the faint smell of urine, but alas, when in San Francisco...) If the whole atmosphere was a little cleaner, and I didn't have to dodge sketchy characters to get through the door, I would maybe bump this up to five stars. To be honest, four is pretty gracious, but it's really because all my hunger pangs were washed away with some of the best nachos and salsa I've had. You've been warned.

I ordered the carne asada suiza quesadilla and it was alright. The carne asada wasn't cut up so I kind of had to tear it apart with my teeth like a wild animal. I wouldn't order it again. As I mentioned, it was the super nachos with al pastor meat that had me lovestruck. Get them. Love them. 

I left so full and so happy. Did I mention it was CHEAP? Literally could not believe that we spent about $50 on a meal for six and had LEFTOVERS. Hangry? Go here.

*Note to self: Buy snacks.
author: Cassie P.

description:
Carne Asada Super Burrito was amazing. Good salsa as well. Looks like an authentic Taqueria. No frills, no nonsense. Just good food, and worth the hype. 

Wasn't too busy on a Sunday afternoon, which was nice. 

Will say that it's not as big as people made it out to be, but I definitely felt full by the time I was finished. It was just so good while eating that I thought would want another one!
author: Jarred V.

description: Like other reviewers have said, this is a hole in the wall, cash only mexican restaurant. They have a lot to pick from and it's all delicious. I got the paro dos which is two HUGE quesadillas, with steak, and the super nachos with chicken. The quesadillas and steak were amazing.. I honestly have no words. It was melted with sour cream and cheese and queso and avocados and incredibly delicious in every bite. The super nachos were the same, they loaded up this plate and there was SOOO much meat!!! They do not skimp out. Make sure you get their tortilla chips and try out the different salsa they have!
author: Julie N.

description:
Huge fan of the food, but not a fan of the line. 

Even though everybody else gets burritos the size of babies, which taste really good, I stick with my carne asada tacos. I've probably gone about 10 times in the past 3 years. They aren't the cheapest tacos in SF, but they are authentic, large (as in lots of carne asada), and taste good. I will usually order 2 tacos per meal. Sometimes I will order 4 tacos just so that I can have some tacos for lunch the next day. I will also order a strawberry agua fresca or horchata and I really love both drinks. 

If there is a line, it doesn't move as quickly as it can. There is no effort made to move the line. So you can either go to another location, as there are a few locations in SF, drive out of the city for their other locations, or come back at a later time and date. 

Once you wait in the line and order, there is a salsa bar. I usually get about 4 containers worth of salsa. And if you want lime, you can just ask people behind the counter for them. They will usually cut up a lime and package it up in foil for you. 

Do expect the service to be slow. Don't expect a smile with your service. I wouldn't bother with the chips as they don't taste very good.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
Highlights
- Shredded chicken super burrito all the way and the chips that they serve here are worth your visit! Comes with all the fix-ins and feels like a hefty monster for the $9 that you just paid for the burrito, good for two meals. 
- Love their self serve salsa bar, I like dousing my burritos in salsa. Don't judge!
- Opened late to fulfill your drunken munchies

Improvements
- Carne asada burrito was alright, nothing amazing. 
- Avocados were lacking in my latest super burrito and the chicken was on the dry side, typically this burrito would be spilling all over with juices from the sauce. 
- Chips are $0.60 extra
- Cramped walkway into the taqueria with the typical long line that they have and waiting around just makes it claustrophobic with people bumping into you.

Tips
- Know what you want, order through phone and just pick up.
author: Tracy T.

description: Recently moved here and had to try a famous mission burrito. All my friends recomended el farolito and I was not disapointed. Small hole in the wall spot with a line down the block so ordered a sesos brain super burrito to go. It was cheap, tasty, and a filling ill be back to try out more of the menu in the future.
author: Sean G.

description: This place has THE BEST MEXICAN food. Once you've had their burritos you're never gonna enjoy any other Mexican food. Try the beef burrito! Especially good! Just beware it's a hole in the wall and slightly rundown place. Great for food ... but maybe not great atmosphere.
author: Maisha R.

description: A dirty, dive-y place with killer, classic, Mission Burritos.  One of the best in town, whether you live here or are visiting.
author: Rob P.

description:
Wow!!! This taqueria is amazing!!! This place is delicious and it serves man sized portions. Authentic Mexican food. 
It's definitely busy in the place, but totally worth it.
Make sure you bring Cash, it's cash only. 
I approve of this place, you won't be disappointed!
author: Kevin S.

description:
TACOS!  

Yeah, this is where you get tacos.  This is genuine, authentic, not fancy, not "California-ized" Mexican food.  Barebones.  Portions are ample, prices are reasonable, and they don't serve tofu tacos.
author: Karen r.

description: Excellent flavor! Tender, juicy, flavorful carnitas. My gf wishes she'd order the carnitas as a platter instead of a taco. If the tacos were slightly smaller, they would have the extra crisp I look for in a soft corn taco. The tripe was fantastic and delicious! We found the salsa to lack a little flavor but, we would definitely return! Very sizable portions and don't forget -- cash only!
author: Daryn L.

description:
It's not everyday that you can get an authentic, Mission taco or burrito if you're not from San Fran. I had this as a bucket list item to get to during a recent week out west and it lived up to its billing.

Now I'm from KC which has a large Hispanic population, so we're blessed to have equally delicious tacos. That being said, the tacos here were amazing. These behemoths are loaded up with meat, and to me, like always, the al pastor is the way to go.

I also tried the asada and the beef toungue which were very flavorful and delicious. The meat quality is good, you won't find popping gristly meat here. 

The hot sauces have some real kick which I appreciate as a lover of all things spicy.

Prices are right, service is quick, and the Modelas are cold. El Farolito for the win!
author: Adam S.

description:
If I could give a negative star I would.  This is my very first review because I want to warn you.  For context, we are proud San Franciscans who love hole in the wall joints and family owned businesses.  I brought my family and out of town relatives to experience great SF Mission burritos. This man apparently the manager takes my order and completely botches it and instead of fixing the situation, he yells at me and then ignores me.  I observed other customers experience this as well.

If that's not bad enough, this place was extremely loud and dirty. You really can't hear yourself think, let alone enjoy a meal. I don't care if the food is good, no one deserves to be treated this way and for goodness sake keep your eating establishment clean. Turns out my two little ones were scared to use the restroom so they held their pee the entire time that's how disgusting it was.

If you come across this place. Run!  Luckily there are plenty of other options like Taqueria Cancun and La Taqueria to enjoy!
author: Cyn C.

description:
Wanted a midday snack.

I pulled out my Yelp app, said, "Yelp, FIIIIND MEEEE TACOOOOOOS!" Bam. El Farolito to the rescue.

The cramped narrow space is laughable as everyone is squeezed closer than sardines in a can. But I must say, it's worth it! Real nachos. Fat tacos. Fresh avocados. Full Vi. Idk what else to say. So you can go read everyone else's glowing reviews.
author: Vi T.

description:
World famous for a reason! Spinach wrap shrimp burrito with Avocado = nomnomnom*

Do yourself a favor and gravitate towards this place.
author: Clouob P.

description:
This was a recommendation from a family member and I'm so glad I stopped here. I heard the carne asada was a must and it was so true. 

The burritos were massive and really tasty but my fave was the carne asada quesadilla. I'd never choose this but got to try it by chance. It was so much better than I thought. The flavors were bold and balanced so well. I would go back for this anytime!

Looove it!
author: Meagan I.

description:
My love for tacos guided me here. I am from NYC and I get my fair share of authentic mexican food there but El Farolito still managed to blow me away with their recipes. I made a tiny mistake of thinking the tacos were small so I ordered some tacos and a platter. No regrets! I know they're known for their burritos but I like my tacos. Everything was delicious! Service was fast and quick. Line up for a bit, the line moves quick, decide what you want, order, CASH ONLY, hold onto your ticket number and they'll bring the food to you. 

They presented the tacos with separated plates for each type of meat, good job! It was easier to remember which meat was which. I devoured everything with a jarritos and what a lovely meal it was. The food was so great that I had almost forgot how it smells like urine and reeking unwashed clothes by the entrance/outside and how there's no effort into the decor and atmosphere of this place. Don't come here to eat if you have OCD. (I don't have OCD.) That's all I'm saying. It was a one time deal for me. The food here is great but I enjoy it more at the spots I go to in NYC, in a clean and fresh venue.
author: Carrie C.

description: Had the super burrito with the cow cow tongue and intestine with everything on it for like $8 bucks! Guys it was huge!!! Big as my whole forearm! Great place fast past and open late till 2:30! Can't beat that! CHeck it out!
author: Joe J.

description:
THIS is the type of place I've been looking for since moving to the bay area. Loud, dirty, tight seats, "CASH ONLY" but delicious Mexican food done right! 

It's conveniently located next to the Bart entrance elevator and in the area of musical festivities, cable cars rolling by and people walking all around and window shopping. 

Waited in line for about 20 minutes and finally got to order:
-1 super burrito with al pastor // definitely worth the $1 upgrade! Huge roll and perfectly seasoned pork. My brother loved it! 

-1 super burrito with carne assada // basic done right! I love that the flavors were so evenly balanced and one didn't over power the other. 

-1 beef tongue taco // yum! To be honest, I love the texture of tongue. Give it a try! Knock down though, on the tortilla. It's not hot enough and definitely one of the meh quality corn tortillas I've had. 

-1 beef head taco // yum! Fatty, big chunks of meat. Perfect! 

-2 al pastor tacos // yum!!! Their al pastor is on point. Just wished it wasn't so choppy though. 

-1 carnitas taco // hmmm. Texture tastes like shredded chicken. If you want something less flavorful, this will be it. 

-1 order of chips // 65 cents for a decent sized basket. Nibble on this while you wait for your order...

Pros:
+good/fast service. Cashier was courteous and efficient. 
+decent prices! For the quantity and quality, this is worth it. 
+good menu! Menu is expansive but seems like most people always go for tacos and burritos! And quesadillas! 
+Good salsa bar!!! I love the avocado salsa...and all the other ones were so spicy but had great kick to it!

Cons:
-Confusing numbering system. You get a ticket with 5 digits, but they only call out 2 numbers?! So...apparently it's the last two numbers. Remember that.

Tips/Observations:
-Cash only!
-They can pretty much customize your burrito but don't be too picky...
-Limited seating inside, but either to-go it or you'll have to share a table or snatch a table. 

Overall, I like it! It would be nice if there was some type of formation for people dining in versus to-go...or else there is literally no space to get water or grab the salsas from the salsa bar.

I REGRET NOT GETTING THE QUESADILLA. SOMEONE, PLEASE GET IT IN MY PLACE.
author: Hurjane V.

description: It's late into the evening hours, you're here. The thick aroma of carne asada and toasted tortillas. You order your food with extra meat and extra guac, cause it's SF you just have to. Your adventurous homie gets the lengua, cause it's the best meat of all. Your vegan homie, get the shrimp burrito cause he can't decide on his allergies this week. Your vegetarian homie chills relleno because its worth it. The girl you're with gets the quesadilla for two.. she tells you that she's gonna share, but will scarf it all down with an xl cup of horchata.
author: Owie P.

description:
4 stars for food/flavor.
3 stars for wait time/crowdedness and generally poorly kept tables/cleanliness.

I had the asada burrito which I generally like and seems to be the most popular item here. It was good and flavorful, but The burritos I've had at La Corneta and Taqueria Cancún we're both more flavorful with much shorter wait times and better kept tables.
author: Jasper P.

description:
Being in San Fransisco as a city alone has been a tremendous experience. The people are cool, the weather is perfect and the food is amazing. 

As a vegan looking for good places to eat in a world full of carnivores has incredible challenges. So you could imagine how amazing it can be when you find a restaurant that caters to your lifestyle. 

If you enjoy Mexican cuisine look to no other place than El Farolito. Located in the culturally affluent Mission district, this place is tiny and tucked away in a slot of 100's of other merchants and retailers. 

The Veggie Burrito with no cheese, no refried beans and (obviously no meat) is heaven wrapped in flour. One bite out of this wrap will send a powerful kick to your taste buds. 

I am 6'6 300lbs and I couldn't finish this thing in one night so I had to finish it the next morning and it was STILL just as amazing as it was when I first but into it. 

If you're in the area definitely check this place out, but don't forget that it's CASH ONLY so don't get caught without it or you will totally miss out, Oh! and you'll miss a spot in line because it will be a long one. 

I would love to revisit someday!
author: Michael J.

description:
Having a burrito in the mission was on our San Francisco bucket list. We searched far and wide and narrowed our options. A chance encounter with a local confirmed our selection of El Farolito. 

This was hands down the best burrito I have ever had and my fiance agreed. We were both smiling. We really enjoy our good. We got the super burrito with shrimp and I was hesitant at first but the shrimp was outstanding. We also went with a super steak quesadilla and that was out of this world too. 

If you are looking for the best burrito, perhaps in the world, go here.
author: Jorge T.

description:
I'm from Texas, and despite what local bay area natives may say, it doesn't get much better than Tex-Mex. I've tried all the other famous burrito places and they were good, but in my heart there was always a special place for the taco trucks near my childhood home (jk, more like college apartment). 

But that was until I had this place. Oh El Farolito. You have single-handedly introduced Mexican back into my rotation of cravings. The one single menu item responsible for that would be the oh so glorious quesadilla.

Now, I never order quesadilla anywhere. To me, the word quesadilla evokes the image of a single layer of cheese between two tortillas. Floppy. Greasy. 

But El Farolito is sooooo not that. The supreme quesadilla is probably one of the most glorious foods I've ever eaten. It somehow is able to house steak, sour cream, avocado, cheese, and who knows what else they put in there. The steak is tender and seasoned perfectly. The healthy dose of sour cream really ties everything together. The tortilla is slightly crispy from the treatment on the griddle, but the inside is soft and gooey. It's perfect.

In terms of the eating experience, don't expect much. You line up, order frantically, (good luck trying to get things like a bag or to-go foil after you leave the counter), try to find a seat in the crowded back area, and hope they call your number soon. But it's okay. Once that food comes you won't even care if you're eating it on the sidewalk.
author: Robin Y.

description: Seriously you can't go wrong when beef tongue and brain is on the menu... but I didn't order it. You know that it is going to be authentic and this place is awesomeness. The place was a little sketch for my wife but was PACKED, which is always a good sign.! The tacos are amazing. I went with 2 carne asada tacos and 1 chicken taco and lookout, the hot sauce has got a little heat.  My wife ordered the nachos and they were great as well. I am from Oklahoma and we know our tacos/Mexican food and THIS place is great!!! Must try.
author: Holden M.

description:
My fav spot in SF for that good flavor filled Mexican burrito or quesadilla fix. 


Carne asada - packed with flavor and cut just right so you get the most out of each bite.  Just makes your mouth water.  

Al pastor - omg (drool) that nice balance of juicy/flavor/spice/grease.  This is always my favorite if they make it good and this place certainly does that.  Try it.  

Burrito - gigantic!  I can put it down and this one beats me every time.  Every bite has a nice balance of meat, and everything else in it.  
  Tip: can only eat these once every 6 mo this or you become el Gordo lol 

Quesadilla- nice and crispy and full of all that good good a burrito has minus the rice and beans.  See above lol 

Atmosphere- dirty.  Definitely not clean or modern.  It's straight eat good food and get the hell out.  Haha.  

Line is usually out the door and cash only so make sure you have time and come hungry.
author: Jason M.

description:
We had a huge discussion about where the best burrito could be found around Mission and decided to have a little taste test... which place truly had the best burrito. I'm sure by this rating you can figure out which one won. El Farolito is by far the best burrito I've had not just in the Bay area but to date. 

We decided to go with the super burrito for our El Farolito taste test burrito. We went with half al pastor/half carne asada per the recommendation of a burrito enthusiast in the group. It was a good choice as the meat itself was so good, so tender, and so flavorful. When they say super burrito they definitely mean super burrito as it's at least 1.5x the size of any other burrito I've seen. The salsas are by far the best I've had (go for green, you won't be sorry).

Finding a seat seems tough when you are standing line watching everyone else enjoy their meals but seats tend to open up more often than not. It's definitely packed though, and expect an extended wait before ordering food (and then getting food) but the wait is worth it.
author: Brent A.

description:
I love Mexican food, I mean LOVE. I would always walk by this place whenever I got off on the 24th and mission Bart stop. Every morning these guys would start early to do all the food prep with fresh ingredients and the delicious aroma would captivate my attention until one day I finally walked in and I was hooked. 

I have tried a number of things on their menu from their standard to their super quesadilla to their burritos and tacos. My favorite is their carne asada burrito paired with their freshly made pico and green salsa which isn't just your average salsa verde, but it has chunks of avocado to make it extra creamy good. Their side of chips for 65 cents gives you a generous portion which you can definitely share with multiple people. It also makes a good scooper for their delicious home-made salsas. 

My only gripe about this place is that parking is tough and the wait is very long. The best way to order is to call them which minimizes, but doesn't eliminate, your wait time.
author: Melissa N.

description:
A few years ago , friends I was hanging with wanted to find this place because they're famous for their amazing burritos. It made a great food memory. 

Fast forward 3 years, in the area again and another friend texted, insisting I go to this place. It wasn't until I walked in the front door that I remembered it. 

Last time I was cautious and went with chicken. This visit, I took my friends advice and went with the super shrimp and a bottle of water. For $14 I got what felt like 2 ponds of burrito heaven. Also they offer free chips and salsa, as authentic joints do. 

I love this place but fear it might get the yelp effect. So ..um,   ....it was awful and I got murdered.  There; I'm yelping from beyond the grave.
author: Mike G.

description: Excellent choice for a great burrito! I love the authentic Mexican food and this place definitely didn't disappoint! Great portions and fast service! Not to mention a very cool area to check out!
author: Derek M.

description:
4 THOUSAND REVIEWS, so what more can I say???? 

One of the best (and worst bc it's so effective on me, the consumer) business strategies of any restaurant is propping up a window that allows patrons to view directly onto the grill/stove/food prep area, ESPECIALLY near the door leading into the restaurant and ESPECIALLY if this restaurant has 4000 reviews and a line out the door no matter what time of the day you go. These windows allow you to gaze with wonder how succulent and juicy the meat looks as they crisp it on the grill, how soft and supple the tortillas seem as the employees gracefully toss them around, how expertly they pile together each mouth-watering component to create something so beautiful and wonderful and heartbreaking (because your stomach can only hold so much) for you. 

I had 3 tacos: shrimp, al pastor, and carne asada. I probably won't order the shrimp again. But my God.... that carne asada taco was one of the best I've ever had. Al pastor was good too, but I think I've had too many good ones in SoCal to be wowed by it. But I was definitely wowed by the carne asada.
author: Gloria P.

description:
Looks amazing but the food lacks taste, esp compared to socal mexican food. Id recommend la tauqeria over this place anyday. 

Pros: huge massive portions and low prices for the bay

Cons: cash only and bland food
author: Atif J.

description: Not for baby!!!! This was recommended but when we walked in the door I realized this is a hard core bar. Don't know how it is but I was told it was really good
author: Lois S.

description: Super delicious. We got the super burrito. It was the size of a small baby. Food was a little greasy, but that's the way it's supposed to be! The burrito was big enough to split between me and my husband. I wish that we lived in Mission so that we could go back weekly!
author: Madison S.

description:
One of the staples of the SF food scene. It's located in the heart of the Mission District, which reminds me a lot of the cantina scene from Star Wars. Lots of weirdos! Had a homeless guy follow me two blocks while screaming gibberish and all while wearing a dress. This might be a perfect time to rant about the mental health care system of our country and it's failings, but I'll save that for another day. Either way, if you're coming here be prepared see a unique line up of characters. 

The restaurant itself is fast and furious and they probably make the best burrito in the SF area. You might think the line is long, but it moves fast. Also the burrito's here? Amazing! The super burrito will leave you satisfied. I tried burritos from over a hundred places, and this is one of the best, and it's very affordable. 

If you're in SF and are craving great Mexican food and don't want to break the bank, then this is your place.
author: Benny H.

description: Best Burrito in the Bay Area , excellent price, excellent food , hands down best i have had in the mission for Price , leftovers always, so much food
author: Robert G.

description: I went to San Francisco on a two-week trip to visit friends. After having one of their delicious, massive burritos, I made sure to go back again before I had to leave. It's a small place with excellent food and quick and friendly service.
author: Danielle A.

description:
Sweet mother of god, this was meaty, cheesy and savory heaven. Every bite pretty much elicited noises that probably aren't socially appropriate. I don't know how this was my first exposure to a Mission burrito but I'm so glad it was.

I had the super burrito with carnitas and it was absolutely glorious. There's something about the whole slices of avocado as opposed to guac and it was amazing. The mix of hot and cold was perfect (none of that one-hot-side-one-cold-side nonsense) and the carnitas were so tender and had great flavor. For $7.75 for a burrito the size of my face and what I could only guess was roughly 2 pounds, this burrito put all other places I've ever had to complete shame.

I will be back for El Farolito. I will be back
author: Jason W.

description: came here for tacos with a friend visiting from singapore, and wanted to show him the mission area past dolo and valencia.  on a random wednesday around 12:30, there was a line to order, and a 10-15 minute wait for tacos. i got three of them - tripe, carnitas, and tongue. all three were flavorful, and the salsas were so delicious as well.  green was probably my favorite. lunch for 2 plus horchata (dont recommend - super sweet) was $25, cash only. would come back for it, though i think the tongue taco was better at la taqueria.
author: Christina L.

description: This place. Wow. The line was super long but it was completely worth it, the Mexican Torta was literally the best torta I have had in my entire life (I am not kidding). Bread was toasted perfectly and the cheese wow the cheese, the picture says it all. The meat was good. It was honestly life changing, I'm not from here but I would definitely go back to San Fran for this torta.
author: Vanessa V.

description:
I've just moved to the Mission District a week ago and every person I had a chat with urged me to visit El Farolito for their burritos. This was my first time here and I wouldn't be lying if I said this is already close to becoming my favorite burrito spot. 

There's a decent amount of seating inside, but you got to be smart about finding a table or you could be waiting for a while since the lines go all the way outside to the front of the building!

I ordered the pollo super burrito with guacamole on the side and it was one of the juiciest and tastiest burritos I've had in my life! They also had multiple options of meat that included chicken, pork and shrimps apart from the delicious looking super veggie burrito.

Great taste and value! Would recommend it to anyone who is in the neighborhood. 

PS - Do try the Mexican sodas. Also, they only accept cash.
author: Gaurav K.

description: It was my first time at El Farolito and I'm definitely going back for quality Mexican food! There was a line at 9pm on a weekday, that says something about the pace. The nachos were definitely my favorite. The portions are pretty large and the flavors are good! As I said quality Mexican at low prices, definitely not the best Mexican I've had but good for the price!
author: Isha R.

description:
#1 best burrito spot in SF. It meets every qualification I'm looking for in a good burrito: cash only, authentic, flavorful, greasy in a good way, large portions, questionable atmosphere and grittyness of a real sf burrito joint with a security guard inside on weekend nights... it's authentic. 

It's not posh like papalotes, it's not overrated like la taq, it's just the real deal. Worth the wait at 1 am on a weekend night. Cash only. Ignore the occasional passive aggressive yuppie that will get annoyed when you snake one of the few bench seats they were eyeing from the line that they assumed was theirs.
author: Ryan G.

description:
It's bold to claim something as the best, but El Farolito's burrito is just that and then some.

In the area that I consider the heart of the Mission, you'll find taquerias every which way you turn. But when it comes to burritos, one stands above them all, and that is El Farolito. Whether it be during lunch, dinner, or after a long night of drinking, there's usually a long line out the door. Although that may deter some from waiting, I find it an experience of itself. The smell of grilled meat greets you, and beckons your attention. The way the staff expertly prepares each order from grilling the tortillas to wrapping the finished burritos is like an art form.

My favorite item on the menu is their super burrito but customized to my liking. I order it with 2 different meats and black beans wrapped in a spinach tortilla. For the meats, I usually go with half carne asada and half lengua, but since the lengua price increase, I've gone with half al pastor instead. The combination of meats create a more complex flavor profile that elevates burrito over the top. And as an added bonus, they don't charge extra for choosing 2 meats, which a lot of other places seem to do. Their salsa bar is also amazing, especially their delicious and addicting salsa verde. I can write a whole review just for their salsa verde.

There are other taquerias nearby that do certain aspects better, whether it be a flakier tortilla, juicier meat, more comprehensive salsa bar, etc, but no one has a better complete burrito than El Farolito. It is the perfect example where the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. With everything (flavor, amount, price, etc) taken into consideration, El Farolito's super burrito reigns supreme. I've been coming to this San Francisco staple regularly for years and won't stop anytime soon!
author: Philip W.

description:
I've always heard about this place, but never made my way to here due to the fact it's in the Mission. It was devastatingly difficult to find parking, especially on a Sat night, but after about 10 min making my rounds, I finally found one right around the block. This restaurant is conveniently located right next to the 24th street bart station, so if I had a choice, I'd bart here the next time I decided I was craving for Mexican burritos. 

As I made my way to the store front, the line was already out the door. About 10 people were ahead of me, but I didn't wait too long for my turn to give my order -- 3 super burritos and super nachos. I just love how the place is so organized and systematic. There's a person who takes your order, writes it up, and gives you the paper to hand over to the cashier who rings you up. Then hands you a number they will call when your food is ready. I would say I waited about 20 min for my order and it's difficult to find a place to sit while waiting. I'm amazed though how big it is compared to when you look at it from the outside. It's actually bigger that I thought it would be and there's about 10 table/benches to sit at. 

As for the burritos and nachos, the portions are worth the price. I think these burritos are bigger than any burrito I've ever had at another place.
author: Tina R.

description: Sucks...not for vegetarians, that's the reason it gets 1 star....oh yea and if you call in don't bother because it doesn't matter...I ended up waiting an extra 30 min after walk ins ordered smh
author: David F.

description:
Quality Mexican food that's open late & lures you in with its long line of people watching the cook prep right by the outside window!

Carne asada burrito is a must if you're really hungry. If not, the super quesadilla will do the trick  since it's still big & packed & sliced in half. 

They also offer fresh carrots & jalapeños to go along with their hot & delicious salsas. Straight cash homie!
author: Roger D.

description:
If you want authentic Mexican food, this is the place  for you. Easily accessible, and they accept debit card. We ordered the regular burrito of carne asada and the meat was spot on in regards to seasoning and tenderness. 

Portions: were pretty big 

They had exemplary customer service! 

Side note: they also have cafe and pan dulce! 

-- Your friendly neighborhood Chicanx
author: Seraina A.

description:
After a few hours of physical activity (moving into my new place, ya filthy minds), my friend and I needed to replenish our energy levels. We stopped by La Taqueria and the line was insane, so we went for the next best option- El Farolito. The first time we stopped by, we only had $2 cash between us. Not enough to buy solid food.This time around, we were prepared. 

He wanted to share a quesadilla, and I'm usually all about sharing, but I was ADAMANT about trying the carne asada burrito. No beans (no farts), add avocado- my go to order.

I took several bites of my burrito, and saw no sign of avocado. I figured they had forgotten, so I asked for some on the side. They must've been really annoyed with me, because they handed me half an avocado without even bothering to slice it. That's fine, I just scooped it out myself. When I got more than halfway through this massive burrito, I started seeing green. Uh oh. 

When will I stop accidentally stealing from restaurants? Is this becoming my new thing in SF? At this point, I opened up the tortilla and realized that all the avocado was back loaded toward the last few bites.  I AM A TERRIBLE PERSON. 

The carne asada meat wasn't memorable, honestly. The quesadilla was okay. I'd only return if the line at La Taqueria happens to be long, or if this is the only spot open late night.
author: Karen S.

description: We usually go to Taqueria Cancun when we're in SF, but the one on mission was closed.  So we tried this place out.  It had a huge lineup so we thought it would be good.  The Carne Asada was really good and the ceviche tostada was fabulous!  The only reason I gave it 4 stars is that the second time we went back the beef in the tacos was kind of burned.  But definitely try the ceviche, it's amazing!
author: Tehmina R.

description: Their burritos are gigantic and so worth the price. You can't beat the deliciousness here. If I'm ever in the mission and craving a burrito, I would definitely make my way to El Farolito to soothe my appetite.
author: Allyson L.

description:
Alright, here's the story: I was visiting SF with some friends, and we were driving back to our Air B&B. We were all tired and hungry after a long day of exploring. I had been craving Mexican food for the longest time so we decided that that would be the best choice for our last dinner in SF. After some searching on Yelp, we found this place. 

It was definitely a little hole-in-the-wall, but the line was out the door. THAT'S HOW YOU KNOW IT WILL BE GOOD THOUGH. I trust the locals!! You can see all the magic happening from the window! Honestly, I remember seeing the meat being cooked and loaded into really fat burritos and tacos... LOOKED SO GOOD IT WAS A SIN. 

I ended up getting a super quesadilla with carne asana to split. And the rest of my friends got burritos. I want to cry just thinking about it. The quesadilla was so good omfg. CHEESY GOODNESS. I'm from LA so I have had my fair share of Mexican food, but this really hit the spot! Oh, and the portions were HUGE. I ended up only finishing half of my quesadilla... Perfect for breakfast the next day though haha!

Blessed to have found this place. It's definitely a great place for some bomb Mexican food late at night. 

PS it was kinda hard to find seating so good luck!
author: Jennifer L.

description: My favorite late night eats. Quesdailla Suiza is a magical creation. Get it if you haven't already. Quesdailla with asada, avocado, and sour cream. BOMB. The lines are long but worth it. Half the patrons are usually kinda sketchy but it really doesn't matter. I'll never stop coming here.
author: Justina V.

description:
I love this place for burritos. Do I love this place at 2 AM when I'm stone cold sober, preggers and dealing with the drunk kids? NOPE, but I don't hold that against the restaurant. Just as everyone has probably already said in their reviews - burritos are delicious, huge, and pretty cheap for SF. 

Just a couple of tips:
- Apparently the location on 24th & Alabama is also open late and doesn't have the massive line. 
- 24th st location is also bigger so you have a better chance of getting a table and won't feel so cramped. 
- This location is Cash only whereas the 24th one takes credit cards
author: Lisa D.

description:
I went to El Farolito today and ordered one Carne Asada Burrito & one Beef Cabeza (Head) Burrito.
the Carne Asada was really good, the Cabeza was just mediocre.
next time I'm sticking with their Al Pastor.

not the best burrito in San Francisco.
for that you have to go to 14th & Church.
author: Rudy H.

description:
Greña with your taco, anyone?

I went up to SF with my wife, son, in-laws and my brother to eat at La Taqueria; it was closed, bummer, I love La Taqueria. We decided to google a nearby taqueria and El Farolito stood out with 4 1/2 stars. The line was long, no problem, it probably meant the food was really good. Nope.

The service sucks, the guy taking the orders had the shittiest attitude. It's a new year guy, smile a little! I ordered three "crunchy" tacos de asada and two regular de tripa. After sitting down, Mr. Smiles, taking the orders, came and informed me that they were out of tripa, okay, I'll have al pastor. 

The tacos al pastor were barely edible. The meat was reheated and dry.

The crunchy tacos were nasty. They were jam-packed with sour cream. I love sour cream with my tacos, burritos and just about everything, but c'mon. The meat quality was really poor; again, it was clearly reheated meat from last year. Taco Bell serves better crunchy tacos, no joke.

Anyway, I love tacos, so I was working my way around the sour cream trying to stay positive when my brother turns to me and shows me a hair in his food. I gave one of the cooks the plate back and he offered me another, no thanks. 

My mother in law was so disgusted she left her wrapped, untouched burrito on the table. Our first and last time at El Farolito.
author: Freddy S.

description: Legit place. Me and the wife were headed to la taquiera which we heard was a staple of san francisco but it was closed unexpectedly. So we walked about about two blocks and saw a line outside el farolito so said this has to be good. And it wasss very good. I got the super burrito with carne asada and my wife got three soft tacos with al pastor , carne asada and a marinated pork. My burrito was ridiculously big but all the ingredients were fresh and the meat was so tender and juicy. My wives tacos were super tasty. Pork was tendor. I mean really i dont see how la taquiera couldve been much better. Be warned though, a lot of homeless in the area. We had a homeless guy come in and ask if we were gonna finish our tortilla chips. They were free so we gave it. But yeah just an fyi. Otherwise frigging delicious spot
author: Pavel N.

description: The Super Burrito with al pastor is all you need to know. When they say "super," they mean SUPER.These are massive burritos that are beyond filling and very reasonably priced. This is a must stop when visiting SF!
author: Melanie T.

description: Good food,good location,Definitely would come back again.Friendly workers  and open late
author: Juan S.

description:
I don't know if i'm missing something or if I went on a bad day (Saturday around 12 AM) but the food was VERY dry and bland. The salsas are not very fresh and lacked depth in flavor. Waited in line for a while for it too. Was not worth it and will try different places next time I want mexican food in SF. 

The store was pretty dirty and all the tables were a little dirty. As expected from a store that has such a large crowd but did take away from the experience of eating also. But it is conveniently located around all the bars so that is one pro about this place!

What I ordered: Al Pastor Burrito (would not recommend)
author: Ori N.

description: Good food. if you go at night, there will be a lot of drunk people. Cash only, but there is an ATM nearby. This place can get rowdy. There was a chick in the bathroom washing her eyes because she got pepper sprayed. Don't let this deter you from visiting. Really good food.
author: Patrick F.

description:
1st up- CASH ONLY. Make sure you've got some ca$h on you when you head out for some dope burritos or tacos or what have you.

I ordered a carne asada super burrito (~$8) so I'm gonna lay it on ya:
-huge burrito (lil ol' me can only eat a half, then save the other half for my next meal)
-super burrito comes with avocado slices (not guac!) and sour cream
-additionally, the regular fixins are beans, rice, cheese, and salsa
-they don't skimp on the meat

They've also got a salsa bar while you're waiting for your food, so make sure to get some of that! The red salsa, I think, was the most tasty on my burrito- not to be confused with the pico de gallo. If you want chips, they're a good $0.65, which isn't that bad!

Make sure to listen for your number, because after you've ordered and paid, they crank out the food and lines tend to get pretty long!
author: Mary F.

description:
Do yourself a favor and order a burrito stuffed with rice, beans, avocado and your choice of protein. I literally dropped my basket on the counter because this thing was monstrous. It weighted about 2 pound (no joke)! All the ingredients in the burrito taste fresh, well seasoned and balanced. I had to take it to go after only finishing 1/4 of it - amazing bang for your buck.

It can be chaotic and crowded, but the exceptional burrito is totally worth the wait. Just make sure to go in with an empty stomach or with 3 other friends who could help you finish the monster burrito.
author: Chi Z.

description:
Definitely a risk/reward situation here (reward: eat one of the best burritos I've ever had; risk: get shanked).  Kidding, but this place is located in the ghetto and often times, the line is so long it runs out the door...and the whole time I was antsy to just get in the restaurant to avoid solicitors. 

The staff operates at high pace to get everybody's orders which, as you would expect, doesn't really leave too much room for manners or cleanliness.  But I got the Super Burrito and the Lengua tacos and they were phenomenal!  It was HUGE, and wasn't overly bean-y like most burritos, and undoubtedly one of the best burritos I've ever had.  Opt for the Super vs the regular so you get the cheese, guac, and sour cream...its so much more worth it.  The lengua tacos were also tasty.

Just remember, it's cash only!
author: Jeff T.

description: I had the shrimp super burrito. Best burrito I've ever eaten. Don't let the look of this place prevent you from enjoying the deliciousness!
author: Renee L.

description:
Another must while in SF, I really enjoyed their al pastor.
Service was nice and they really work the crowds well.
Best item here is the quesadilla, great value, tasty cheese and when you spruce it up with the salsa from their salsa bar you have a cheap and filling meal.
The store is pretty small and run down, count on a long line and a hard time finding a place to sit.
Cash only but they have an ATM around the corner, tasty treat while in SF.
author: Nijole T.

description: Best tacos in the city. Come try out the cheesy grilled chicken quesadilla and the tacos (yum!)! You won't regret. I have yet to try out their burritos but I'll be back for those as well (I always end up getting those tacos though). Great pairing with their sauces as well!
author: Monica L.

description:
Another place I finally got to try out El Faro!

Line was long right outside of Bart, waited about 15-20 minutes to order, and got my order within 10 minutes, they were quick!

I was looking at what other people had ordered and the portions are huge!

I ended up getting 2 regular tacos and 1 crispy taco, it was pretty filling!

That carne asada is on point, definitely recommend. The Super Size burritos look huge, that will be the next thing I order the next time I come around.

There was a live band playing in the back for someones bday.

Salsa bar is simple, green, red, hot, jalepeno+onions
author: Elijah B.

description: I tried this place during my short stay in San Francisco and I cannot wait to go back! My entire family loved loved it! Burrito is a must try! Don't forget cash only. We tried tacos, burritos, and quesadillas all delicious and they come in large portions so come hungry or ready to share!
author: Lynnette V.

description:
One of the very few places that's open till late, you can explain the long waiting lines on a Friday night :P. 

We were actually aiming for La Taqueria (which we had already been to) but it was shut so this place is literally 5 min away so we decided to give it a try. 

We had to wait about 15 min (and people keep getting into the line so it never ends) and we shared a beef taco, super beef burrito and steak quesadilla between three of us and paired it with couple beers. Taco was ok (not a big fan), the burrito was nice but the star of the show for all of us was the quesadilla - it was juicy and delicious and not too cheesy like it can be sometimes. 

Place is not so clean and quite rowdy so be prepared for that type of scene. Will surely be back! Ah, yes the green avocado sauce is superb and one of a kind!
author: Heliana M.

description:
This place was SOLID. I don't know what the hell they did to their rice, but I wanted to build a castle with it and live inside. The burrito was bomb, the quesadilla BOMB. Couldn't wait til lunch I had the leftovers for breakfast in the mownin.

Nothing beats a place where you clean off your own table like you would at your best friends house, wiping the crumbs off the table to just fall on the floor among the other crumbs and whistle over the dog to eat it. You'll walk out with a tortilla stick to your shoe, debating whether to eat it or not.
author: Becky A.

description: Very bad food I need veggie burrito he give me chicken burrito all working guys not good I never coming again this please I don't like this place
author: Pardeep C.

description: The best Mexican restaurant in San Francisco, it's sooo good that you are not gonna believe, the sizes are really big, I think you are gonna love it
author: Murat U.

description: It's 3am and you have drunk munchies. If you're in SF, there's only one place you need to know about. It's El Farolito. They're famous for a reason. My favorite here is the shrimp quesadilla but you can't go wrong with any of their burritos either.
author: Mike A.

description: So good! Alwasys hectic but worth the wait. CASH ONLY!
author: Yeonhwa S.

description:
The super suiza para dos is pretty much the best thing ever after leaving a bar. You need four people or two really hungry people to finish it. This is are full size tortillas used as the sides of the quesadilla. It has you meat of choice(carne is the best) , cheese, avocado, and sour cream. Then they grill the whole thing to perfection. The burritos are good but you really have to get the super suiza. The nachos we're not great. They also have a good salsa bar with red and green salsas that range is spiciness day to day. 

There is pretty much always a line out the door but it moves fast some times it takes a while to get your food, but you can call ahead if you can get them to answer the phone. 

The seating is crowded and not the best, but some times you just don't want to wait for your super suiza.
author: Megan Q.

description: A friend recommended and I wasn't disappointed. Place was packed which is always a great sign. I got the carne asada burrito with extra cheese and extra sour cream. Each cost $1.75 but I got my money's worth.  GREAT burrito!
author: Jason G.

description:
My go to for all sorts of Mexican food. Quick and easy. Expect long lines depending ont he time of day you go. 

Food is overall fantastic!

A complaint is that they have slow and i mean really slow cooks to prepare orders that they had to tell customer that they have 30+ orders wait time. i waited myself for 1.5 hours i was DISAPPOINTED!

Otherwise great food. 

Because of the bad experience 2 weeks i gave them a 3 stars. Nobody should wait 1.5 hours and for you to refuse customers and tell them you cant take their order and or tell them there is an hour wait because your prep cooks that prepare the food is SLOW AF. Dead wrong!
author: Meishi M.

description:
I'm not a huge fan/believer in San Francisco style burritos because let's face it, we don't have anything on San Diego Mexican food. I'm a true San Franciscan and will stand up for anything this city has to offer but, taco shops are not our strong suit. That being said, there are a few decent spots in San Francisco and I'd rank El Farolito around #3 or 4. 

In the decade I've lived in San Francisco, I've been to El Farolito a few times. I'm not turned off by "dirtier" kinds of restaurants so, no points knocked there. My most recent trip was a couple weeks ago and I ordered the carne asada burrito. It's a standard taco shop kind of order and tough to go wrong. The tortilla was excellent, the salsa way too spicy and overall just an A-OK experience. The chips are super disappointing because they aren't made in house and I feel like I'm getting cheated out of an authentic experience.

The best part about this place is the fact that they stay open late. When you can't get to La Taqueria in time, then this is a viable option. Mic drop.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
Where do I start? El Farolito is my favorite spot for Mexican EVER. Haven't found a place to beat it yet and I doubt I will. Sigh, too bad it's so far from sac but a must whenever I visit sf. 

I always get the carne asada super burrito and it's the size of a baby! Lol. You definitely can't beat the price.  Back of the alley kind of place and it can be very hard to find parking. This place is always jam packed and extremely busy.  Came in here one night after a concert around 2 am and it was still very lively. Dirty tables, dirty bathroom but I feel that's all part of the experience here. 

El Farolito had my heart!!! Please make one in sac
author: Brittany V.

description: Stumbled here from Yelp. The location is not the best. There's a bar next to it and there were a bunch of drunks fighting over a burrito lol. The line gets pretty long and it moves waaaaaay too slow. We had a burrito and a quesadilla, both were good and tasty, but nothing special and definitely not worth the 25+ minute wait. Probably won't be back.
author: Claudia E.

description: Cash only- good food, good quantity, totally worth it.  The quesadillas are what they are famous for- I got chicken, I also tried the pork tacos (spicy, but good) and the beef super burrito.  They have free sauces that are good, so be sure to pack some if you are taking it to go.  If you get there early, the wait isn't too bad.  I also bough their flan which is made in house, and totally good as well.  I walked a mile to get here and it was worth it!
author: Lily F.

description:
I love coming to El Farolito. Definitely one of my go-to spots for a late night burrito since they are open late! 

Please be noted, it's cash only. 

Secondly, be noted that I've seen orders get mixed up sometimes so definitely check your receipt. It's 1:30am and the line is out the door, it's bound to get confusing. 

Third, trying to find a table? Usually one will clear up because everyone's pretty good on the eating and leaving. I've never had trouble and everytime I've been here, it's been packed. 

Fourth, salsa is great but I've been here on some nights and it'll burn you up. While other nights, it is super mild. So good luck to you on what kind of salsa night it'll be.
author: Arezou A.

description:
I mean, the food here is great. But I just had a pretty shit experience... show up at like 1:15am, wait in line until about 1:30am (so far, normal), order super carnitas burrito, at 2am it still hasn't been called, ask a dude what's up, he seems convinced he already gave me my food (he didn't), finally get burrito at around 2:10am, go home, open it, and it's a totally different (shitty) fucking thing with no meat at all (?!?!?!?!). No mames...llevo una pinche hora esperando para nada.

Pissed off enough to try some other late night food after this. ugh.
author: R G.

description: Waited 30 mins in line took one bite of my burrito and found a giant long black hair...disgusting. They need to wear hair nets!
author: scott d.

description: Excellent burritos, tacos and enchiladas. The meat has great flavor that regardless of what you get it's gonna be delicious. Will definitely return
author: Yama Q.

description: This is my favorite go to burrito place. Massive portions, Double meat no needed. And it closes at 3:30am so it's a place for hungry drunk ppl.
author: rob a.

description:
Great quite Mexican food. Hole in the wall place. Narrow and few tables at the back. Good for takeout. 
The ordering is a but hurried. The staff can be a bit rude but they just doing a good job to keep the line  moving. 
They have water in the front and also some salsa which you can help yourself. 
Good place to go after drinks. They also have beer.
author: Amit K.

description:
Where else does one go for food before a redeye but El Farolito?

Brace yourself- It's chaotic and it'll take time to get your food. Know this, but don't let it stop you from going. 

Went around 8:30pm on a Sunday. Probably took about 30-40 minutes from the moment I stepped on line until I got my order. While I wasn't in much of a rush, those who were did not have a good time (a person ahead of me started screaming at the poor employees because she had yet to get her food... as if she was the only one waiting and as if the folks weren't working hard enough already). Luggage in tow in the small space, I was constantly in the way, but I persisted and patiently waited for what some consider the best Mexican food on either coast. Very glad I did. 

The wait is a bit tortuous as the line curves around the front window where you can see every order being made. It was fun to watch the production line- it was clear they know what they're doing and they do it well. Everything looked sinfully delicious. After much debate, I ordered a super burrito with carne asada. Generous portions of every single ingredient that work incredibly well together. You can taste every element -- the flavorful carne asada was enveloped by the perfectly seasoned rice and beans, held together by huge chunks of avocado (each burrito gets at least a half an avocado), cheese, and sour cream. Three or four servings easily (or one, if drunk). I swear it was the size of a large child.

Cash only. Know your order when it's your turn. 
Grab a number (in the meantime, get yourself some salsa/guac- it's self serve), and wait until your number is called. It's like the lottery, except you always win.
author: Rosa Y.

description:
Al Pastor Super Burrito has certainly changed my perspective of El Farolito. The pork flavor really shined through and brought a great sense of comfort. I hear the chicken is even better so I will definitely be back to give that a shot as well. 

Portions continue to be massive and great for the price in comparison to La Taqueria 

My only gripe is that they don't spread the ingredients evenly across the burrito 

Overall Thoughts

See you soon El Farolito!
author: Eddie W.

description:
I had the carne asada burrito. It's pretty big so I would recommend sharing one with another person unless you're really hungry. It tasted pretty good. There aren't many ingredients in the burrito - just meat, rice, beans (maybe that's how authentic burritos are, not sure). I asked if they could add some lettuce. I enjoyed the spicy green sauce that you can get yourself from the counter. I also noticed that the water was tinted slightly brown although it tasted fine.
BRING CASH!!!
author: Rachel K.

description:
I grew up in San Francisco and when I first had this, I was thinking to myself, where have you been all my life. Probably because I don't hang out in the Mission too often. WOW it was amazing. I got their **SUPER BURRITO with Carne Asada. It's FREAKEN amazing! So much flavor. Made with soft flour tortilla prepared with rice beans (I ALWAYS say without, extra rice instead), fresh, tomato, onion, cilantro, salsa, cheese sour cream and avocado. It was 2am when I had it the first time. But I went back during the day and it was still as DELICIOUS as I remember! 

The only bad thing is that its pretty dirty, I mean that homeless comes in and out. I just take it and go. Fast services. Eat it somewhere else.
author: Sandy B.

description:
El Farolito is definitely a gem of San Francisco and lives up to the hype. After many night outs in the city, this was my first time surprisingly at El Farolitio. My impression of this place is the definition of divey (hole in the wall, small restaurant) and it is great that it is open late at night. This is also cash only place. I could imagine this place being a 'go to' spot after hitting the bars or clubbing. 

My friend and I went here late at night after a concert, there was still a good amount of people here. You don't come here for the cleanliness, you come here for the food. I had the Al Pastor Super Burrito and my friend got the quesadilla, and both were huge! It was so big that I saved some for the next day and ate it for breakfast and lunch. It also so good that I didn't really need to add sauce. I highly recommend this place if you are a foodie and have a love for mexican food. El Farolito will be the first thing that comes to mind after a night out in the city.
author: Alliver V.

description: El farlito is the worst I called in to make a phone order to pick up and first of all no one spoke English second she counsels the hear or understand me and third I asked her for the total and she said i don't know the tottal that's not my job el farlito sucks never call here again!
author: Ramzy H.

description: Hole in the walls always have the best food and this place is no exception. I ordered my food, two tostadas, right before the rush of people came in. Usually there is no where to sit but there is a park nearby where you can eat. I preferred the carne asada taco over the chicken although the chicken was well seasoned.
author: Ashley P.

description:
You ever get frustrated by a restaurant for something, like they made your order wrong, it took forever, someone on the staff was rude, etc. but then the food is so freakin' good you have to stop being so stubborn and let it go?

That's how I feel about El Farolito. I came here last Monday evening (August 7) with a friend around 7pm and the line was almost to the door -- that was probably the shortest it was the whole time we were there but it moves pretty quickly.

Side note: this place is CASH ONLY so don't wait in that line only to find out you don't have enough cash at the register!

I ordered us the quesadilla para dos: flour tortilla, cheese, steak (or another meat of your choosing, we went with al pastor), sour cream, and avocado for $12.45 but TIMES TWO. This meal is ideal if you and a friend, a date, or a future, hungover you tomorrow morning, both want the quesadilla super suiza (super delicious, amirite??) and are down with the same protein choice.

Here's where I got excited and then sad. The cashier asked if we wanted the sour cream and avo inside or outside, and I was elated to shout OUTSIDE since we all know how i feel about avo. More later.

We were lucky enough to get a table (kind of dirty but we got hands, we can clean up for ourselves) and there, we patiently waited. Finally, essentially a pile of quesadillas came to us....!

With sour cream and massive slices of avocado INSIDE. My heart broke. The picky eater in me almost lost her appetite. "Minus one star!" I said to my friend half-jokingly. But at a place this busy, I couldn't bear to be "that guy" who takes two whole quesadillas up to the counter to say, "um excuse me, but I'm super white and don't like avocado, so could you trash this perfectly good food and remake it for me despite your long af line? k thx" so I did what any rational person does, and I pulled out every scrap of avo I could from the pieces I ate and gave them to my avo-loving homie.

And good lord was this quesadilla great - I love quesadillas but this was one of those where you just close your eyes as you chew to really savor the taste. The al pastor had just a little bite to it but was so juicy, I had reddish orange grease running down my hands. I really appreciated how generous El Farolito was with the meat as well as the sour cream (and for an avo lover, the sliced avo). And their salsas are pretty good! The green sauce had more of a kick to it than some other tomatillos I've had but it was great. The hottest one wasn't quite hot enough for my friend but he said it was still tasty.

Overall, this place was an awesome dinner -- a cheap meal that was super delicious and super worth the line, despite my order being wrong. Next time, maybe we'll order separately so I can just say no to avocado.
author: Keridwyn R.

description:
