I absolutely love this place! I usually get the super burrito and let me tell ya, IT IS WORTH IT! I've come here a couple of times and every time that I do come here, there is a long line. The lines goes by pretty fast though and again, this is definitely a place that is worth the wait. Service is good, food is delicious, cash only, and the restrooms are VERY dirty/small (but sometimes you gotta go when you gotta goo...). 

10/10 would come back here anytime of the day.
author: Amy L.

description:
Forget the 5lb weights at #soulcycle - I'm gonna ride or die with these heavyazz Super Burritos in each hand from now on. #upgraaaaadde

#finally tried this place for the 1st time #feliz2016 on a random #satunchdaylunchday with a line out the door. Got the TRIPAS = INTESTINE and SESOS = BRAIN. Otherwise, I'd go for the Lengua, maybe Cabeza; y'all #basicfoodies can have the rest. ¿Puede siquiera comidas aventureros hermano?

There were a whole 2 black people (not counting myself) and like 3 non-employee Mexicans (still not counting myself). #blacktacosmatter #alsomexicantacos Sadly, not much hipster action.

PS: Get salsas at the sidebar unless you like blandness.
author: Dan B.

description: The food speaks for itself, don't even contemplate coming here just do it. I didn't even have time to take a photo before my burrito was gone.
author: Alan L.

description:
good: open til late; authentic grub; cheap; generous portions too!
the irony: you probably don't want to be in this area at after hours, which was why we ended up there in the first place. and there's always a queue, no matter how late. 

menu is pretty standard mexican street grub, but food has been consistently tasty. I appreciate how they follow authentic recipes and ingredients in their tacos: mixed beans, melted cheese, avocado, rice, served in a traditional soft corn tortilla instead of the tiny ones. 

points to remember: cash only; watch out for sticky counters and taco sauce-stained seats! you may want to bring some extra napkins.
author: Fiona F.

description: I'm no taco snob or anything, but this place is WAY overrated. I'll give them the tortillas (they might be homemade) and the salsa bar, but I had the steak normal tortilla taco and chicken crispy shell taco and it was all meh. Meat quality is important since it's like 80% of what makes the taco and overall it was dry no texture well seasoned. Definitely not worth the wait.
author: Don G.

description:
Get the quesadilla para dos ($12.75), flour tortilla, cheese, steak, sour cream, avocado. Well worth it whether you're eating it alone or with someone else, it can actually feed four to be honest. 

The line is always out the door. The seats are perpetually filled. The food, forever amazing. They have beef tongue and intestine too! Way better than any of those hipster tequila bars that serve up 5 tacos for $30. 

Order everything off their menu in whatever state you may be in because you will not regret the quantity and you will love the quality. Wish they made quesadillas like that in Boston... Area can be sketch, by the hospital especially, but the main street this joint is at is chill.
author: Nancy H.

description:
This place is amazing!  Open late (past bars closing) and awesome food!  Their quesadillas are delicious, and their burritos are pretty amazing too.  Very conveniently located around the Mission, so it's great for grabbing some food after drinks.

The biggest downside is probably the line, but the wait's not terrible and the food's totally worth it.
author: Keith C.

description: Dope late night food. Interesting conversations started and great prices. Ate half as drunk food and ate the other half after I got back to my place in Chicago. Next time im getting Pastor but the steak was fantastic
author: George N.

description: I love this place. I was in the area for five days and probably ate here four times. The tacos are authentic and delicious, with a lot of meat. I personally liked the carne asada tacos the most but all taste amazing!
author: Sana M.

description:
We came here for lunch since La Taqueria was closed. Got the carne asada tacos which were pretty yummy. 
But after looking at the other pics wish I'd tried the super nachos which look hecka good
author: Linda W.

description: Still good, but not as good as it used to be. Everything seems a bit more sloppy, the burrito looked like it exploded. Will probably still continue to come here though =)
author: Collin W.

description: I had their steak and shrimp burrito many many years ago and I still dream about it to this day. Yes I did eat it after hanging out with friends all night, so that might have influenced my taste buds a bit but until proven otherwise, I still claim this place to have the best burrito I've ever eaten.
author: Justin C.

description: This wAs one of the top Mexican authentic restaurants that we have been to! If you are looking for a really good comfort food done right, this is the place to be at!
author: Sephi S.

description:
I've wanted to review El Farolito's OG location for a while now since it is a San Francisco insitution (and Kaskade's favorite burrito joint). However, given my heavy heavy bias towards Mexican food from San Diego, I wanted to make sure that I would be able to give (as much as possible) a fair assessment. Multiple visits have ensued since my first time here. And now that I've had a decent chunk of this menu, it is time to finally lay down my thoughts.

My problem was that my original decision was to take the super burrito straight up...including beans. Perhaps my preference is born out of SD-style burritos, where there are basically never any rice or beans included. I know there are those who love beans in their burritos. My opinion is that unless you are eating a bean and cheese burrito, beans have zero business being in a burrito because they are straight filler that are meant to distract you from what really matters...the MEAT. (For the record, I am ok with rice as that doesn't really distract me from the meat).

Anyways, now that we cut out the beans (and sour cream too, sacrifices have to be made in my old age) and get down to the real business, El Farolito has a solid burrito. Definitely better than your average SD or LA Mexican joint. Their carne asada and al pastor are pretty good...nowhere near the best I've ever had, but definitely in the above average range. Also, I think the rice complements the meat pretty well. Still would've preferred guacamole over avocado, but eh it is close enough. Bonus points for the burrito keeping VERY well after a flight back to Los Angeles and being microwaved a day after.

Being such a popular spot, sometimes it does get very crowded and seats become impossible to find here (I'm looking at you 2 AM crowd). And I do wish they had a non-cash option, but it is what it is. However, it has prime location (and I mean PRIME) right off of the 24th Street & Mission BART stop. If you're ever taking the BART down to SFO and you need a great meal that's super quick and cheap, you won't find a better option.

Overall, El Farolito is a solid Mexican spot and I won't ever complain if I come here for any of my SF meals. But it is not elite-level Mexican food. Compared to my SD spots, there is no comparison.
author: Alexander Y.

description:
Despite the the fact that the "Mission" is jam packed with Mexican & Latin food on every corner, this place will forever be one of the greatest establishments for traditional fare. This restaurant has you covered from A to Z, no matter if you are mid morning breakfast person fueling up for work or if you are a night owl who needs some food to soak up booze. 
  The menu is fairly large here, they offer everything from tacos and burritos to menudo and pozole, and though everything is very tasty, the quesadillas are one of their best items. The cheese on the quesadillas is always melted to the point that it is oozing out of the middle, the meat is cooked to a crispy(not burnt) texture, and the tortillas are grilled to a beautiful golden brown color. Also, this restaurant has an excellent self serve salsa bar with every spice level from mild to spicy, and they offer some of the tastiest brined carrots and jalapeños around the neighborhood.
author: Joseph A.

description: Carne Asada here is wayyyy better than the carnitas. Always satisfies the late night burrito munchies/drunchies since it's actually open late! El Farolito will always have a special place in my heart as the OG greasy, filling, monster-size, SF burrito!!
author: Nicole L.

description:
I thought this place would be amazing because of all the positive reviews but I was disappointed because my chorizo breakfast burrito lacked flavor and barely had any meat. Instead it was filled with mostly rice and beans and some pieces of avocado. 

The tacos were descent size but also the meat lacked flavor. 

I went to the bathroom area to wash my hands and walked into a swarm of flies hovering around. The bathroom was absolutely disgusting. I wouldn't come back here again.
author: Jenny C.

description: By far the best burrito I've had. Granted, I was practically raised on the stuff. Amazing quality. Can't go wrong with anything on the menu.
author: Mario E.

description:
First time here with my buddy.

The line was very long, here were 12 people infront of us, we waited around 15 mins. 

I ordered 2 chicken tacos and 1 shrimp taco
My buddy ordered pork super burrito 

All tasty but the wait was a little longer than we exacted.
author: Mack A.

description:
Stopped at EL FAROLITO the other night on the way to the Bill Graham Civic Auditorium. I had only been to the San Jose branch and found it underwhelming to say the least. While this place is an absolute DUMP - the food was super duper legit! 

Ordered the Super Carne Asada Burrito - no crema. It came with free chips and salsa, and I also ordered a Negra Modelo. The burrito was huge and tasty, everything about it was near perfection. I'd return in a heartbeat!

4.75 stars!
author: Joel V.

description: This was my first time trying this place and I must admit that I saw the long line and didn't want to wait but I'm glad I did. It's so busy and while one person orders the other needs to keep an eye out for a table to become available or you take it to go. The tacos, burritos and even quesadillas are huge!!! I like that you can watch them cook and prep everything. The guys are moving non stop. I will definitely be back to try something else
author: Kassondra L.

description:
A stable of SF. El Farolito is prob one of the best, most well known, late night taco joints in SF. After spending 8 years in SoCal, I was so sad moving back to the city and not being able to get my taco fix. Yay for El Farolito, I need to look no more. This place is always packed. Super long lines (that move quickly). Honestly, they just have good, wholesome, authentic Mexican food. I've tried several of their meats and they're all on point. Their asada is on point and flavorful and their lengua, super tender.

Most definitely will come back. **seating can be hard to find, especially during peak hours.
author: Diane T.

description:
If you want a high-end dining experience that includes Mexican food, El Farolito is not that place. If you're willing to look beyond the cramped space, subpar cleanliness and presumable long line, you'll likely be able to appreciate the glory this place contains. 

Bring cash, and prepare to enjoy one of the best burritos I've ever encountered.
author: Gia R.

description:
I dropped someone off at the Oakland airport, then drove one exit away and hopped on a Milbrae BART just to eat here. 

The outside isn't appealing, but it hides the most delicious Mexican food I have ever consumed. You'll be lucky to find a table, but you will be content for the taste of the food you receive. I had the camarón burrito (shrimp) and my brother had the carne asada. Both were PHENOMENAL!

The price is decent, taste is amazing, and the trip is worth it!
author: Klo P T.

description: Best Chile relleno burritos anywhere. Must stop every time we visit SF. Chips always fresh, delicious salsas. I always take a few burritos to go, for later.
author: E B.

description:
Walking out of the 24th & Mission BART station, hungry after a night of drinking/dancing, nothing makes you happier than seeing the bright yellow sign atop this spot as your mouth drools a bit for the carne asada super burrito.

And then you get to the door, and it's packed...hard to find a seat, long lines, and mess on all the tables. But you still stand in that twenty minute line b/c well...burritos...and food...and burritos. And then you wait. And wait. And then you think it's your number, but they call the one after you, so you wait a little bit more...Aaaand you get your number, grab the burrito, put some salsa on there, and it's totally worth it - more than worth it. It's the best burrito in that moment that you ever tasted. And you eat. And eat. And soon it's gone. And you feel stuffed - satisfied, but stuffed.

This has happened to me on many an occasion, and I love El Faro, but once in a while it doesn't taste like before, or the line is too ridiculous, so I'd say a solid 4.5 stars. Keep it up, El Faro.
author: Brandon Y.

description: A must have if you are traveling to SF. Can't go wrong with any of the dishes on the menu. My fav are the burritos and quesadillas! Place is a bit small but that's the experience!
author: Jt G.

description:
My most obsessed about Burrito place since it was named #1 on a SF food list. Many care to disagree with me but I have yet to be disappointed. I've been here dozens of times but it's as consistent as it gets. 5/5 stars since it stays open late making it the most accessible place to grab my fave drunchie foods after going out in the city. 

I tend to stick with either the carne asada super burrito or carne asada super suiza (after being recommended by someone else in line). Both come in huge portions and for under $8 each you basically have 2 meals. Lines can be out the door which takes the most time, but once you order you get your order fairly quickly. They don't skimp on the avocado too which is a big plus! The horchata here isn't that great imo so I don't care to get it here even when i'm a fan of the drink.

Great quick, affordable, and great place to satisfy my fix! Even if you're not craving this place, it's in the mission so you have other awesome alternatives in the area that are in walking distance. It's also right off BART so it's easy to get to as well.
author: Keizzel C.

description: I guess I just caught it on a bad day...  The burrito outweighs ALL of what I said previously. Great burrito. Of course I came back. And I couldn't let that 3 star review represent my experience any longer. I've been converted!
author: Jo G.

description: Holy Burritos!!!!!!!! So delicious. Got 3 to bring with me on the plane and wish I would have brought more. Cash only so keep some on you to make sure you can get some! Friendly guys making delicious food.
author: Vanessa A.

description: My first time here and I will definetly come back again. They have Super good burritos and tortas! Great prices also!
author: Alex H.

description: My favorite taqueria in SF! The line may be out the door, but totally worth the wait!
author: Cato M.

description: Great after hours food. There are clubs and bars in SF that don't get this busy. There are more women here than some of the clubs I go to. There is a line to get in too. But it moves very fast. You can see it. It's kind of exciting.
author: Rigo R.

description: While working in the city over years this place has been a main stay. And will always be as long as it stays around. I swear to all of you that chipotle was buipt off of the back of this place and others like it.
author: Robert P.

description: Unbelievable food. Highly recommend the quesadilla super suiza. Line moves pretty fast, but can definitely get crowded.
author: Kevin C.

description: Cool spot! The food was awesome and the services was even better! When it comes to Mexican food, this is the place! The panaderia next door was a bonus! A Latino will always fine Latinos no matter where we go, I visited it twice and was pulled away from my third trip by my coconut kids!
author: Manny C.

description: For your late night Mission burrito craving when every other place is closed, El Farolito does the trick.  You'll have to wait in a decent-sized line, but it moves quickly and you'll be able to people watch while you wait - young professionals, blue collar workers, college-aged kids, people who may or may not have a place to live, etc.  Soon enough you'll be rewarded with an enormous burrito.  It'll be far from the best burrito you've ever had, but it fits the bill, solves your hunger pangs, and helps absorb all that alcohol you've imbibed.  I tried a bit of asada, carnitas, and shrimp recently, and shrimp was the unanimous winner.
author: Chris C.

description:
This place is legit.  It's in the ghetto for sure, but it attracts people from all walks of life.

Everything we had here was delicious.  All the items have an abundance of flavorful meat and cheese.  The green salsa was pretty good.

Coming from So. Cal., it takes a lot for me to be impressed with grimy Mexican joints.  This was impressive.  I'm coming back next time I'm in SF.
author: Phil N.

description:
Can't go wrong with this classic in the mission district. 
Open late until 3am for your late night 4th meal. 

Very heavy burritos!
My favorites are al pastor or carne asada. 

It's nice to have options other than dirty dogs after 2am that's quality food.
author: tsubasa m.

description:
CASH ONLY

Such great flavors, so much food for super cheap! You walk in and you see the cooks freshly cooking the meats to be served, makes me salivate thinking about it. Authentic Mexican foods with pretty special meats to go in your order from carne asada, al pastor, carnitas, grilled steak, to lengua, and beef brain. 

I got the Super Burrito which comes with rice, beans, tomatoes, onion, cilantro, salsa, cheese, sour cream and avocado. IT was SO GOOD, and HUGE!. I love how they melt the cheese inside. Their tortilla chips are also very good! Addictive with their self-serve salsa bar! I love the green sauce! 

If I am ever back, I will get the super quesadilla suiza! It looks bomb..
author: Christie L.

description: Great little place in mission.  Since this place already has such good reviews I wanted to first state something different than everyone else.  This neighborhood is really not as sketchy as everyone says it is, it's in the city, there are homeless people, it's not a big deal - they're not looking to rob you.  Anyways... the people in this place are really friendly.  The food is pretty cheap considering how much food you get.  I would definitely recommend coming here if you want Mexican food and are nearby.  I'll probably hit the spot up again if I'm in SF proper.
author: Alexander C.

description: Quesadilla super suiza is on point. It's always a good idea to try what's on the sign. This place is a go to for us when we head into the city. Super bomb Mexican food. The environment is what you'd expect in the mission. It's busy pretty much all the time.
author: Karson K.

description: My suggestion is to keep your order as simple as possible, any variation causes mass confusion between the order taker and the preparers. In our burritos, almost everything was wrong, but I understand their confusion. Despite getting the orders wrong the ingredients were fundamentally tasty. I'm biased, but I still like La Tapatia Super carnitas burritos in South San Fran the best. I'm still searching for exceptional carne asada like the taco truck on highway 41 near NAS Lemoore back in 86. Just a dream i guess.
author: Michael A.

description: One of the better tacquerias in the mission. You can get a fat burrito for 8 bucks. I love the carne asada, and paired with a corona, you have a true winner. Plus they have delivery until late into the night, so that is always a huge plus...right!!!?!
author: Ross S.

description: Great quality, no-frills burritos for an excellent price. The line wasn't too bad when my group of four stopped by, and it went by quickly. We were able to get a table (score!) and the food came out quickly. My carne asada burrito was delicious, and the portion was huge, so I was able to save half for breakfast the next day. Be sure to bring cash!
author: Sarah B.

description: Best Mexican food in SF. Cash only but there's an ATM nearby. They make the food right there in front of you and sometimes have a mariachi band playin in the back. Great prices for SF. It's always busy so be ready to wait in a line, but it doesn't take super long. I Highly recommend trying it out!
author: Sierra S.

description: I really wanted to like this place...actually went out of my way to try their burrito given its reviews on Yelp. First off...parking is a problem. Secondly...huge line. Lastly...they are in such a hurry to serve all the customers that they tend to mix different meats up. I don't eat beef or pork but felt as if I could taste it in my chicken burrito. Not big on sanitation this place. Only accepts cash. I should have instead gone to my go-to Papalote. Huge disappointment!
author: Jatin M.

description:
Best place in San Francisco for burrito!!!!

Crazy hectic line but totally worth it. Always so fresh and HUGE portion. I can never finish but happy to have left overs. 

This is the spot to be after clubbing or a night out. It's not my favorite to eat there because of how jam packed it gets but I'll put it with it if I'm hungry. 

So many good sauces and quick service. CASH ONLY!!!

The only reason why I didn't give them 5 stars is because they mess my order up here and there. I'm pretty simple when it comes to burritos and they usually leave my sour cream out or accidentally add beans even though they read their order to me confirming it.
author: Allison S.

description: Very tasty food. Quick service. Cheap prices. Can be crowded. But... In general, very good place, I recommend to visit it!
author: Jose S.

description: Amazing food! A total dive inside and could have used without the homeless man showering in their sink behind where we were eating, but it sure is an "authentic" experience. The quesadilla and nachos were delicious, food is hot, fresh, and fast. I would for sure return here. We did find the men playing guitars at back and asking for money to be annoying while we were trying to eat, but it's the city.
author: K R.

description:
I've tried El Farolito a handful of times, at the Excelsior and South City locations. Those few times, I wasn't impressed with their super suiza, compared to La Guadalajara's quesadilla. 

Just a few days ago though, I came in with my mom and gave it another shot. I was satisfied to say the least. The tortilla was warmed to toasty perfection, the cheese was nice and melty, and as a whole, the dish wasn't too messy - just the right amount of grease. My boyfriend and I always preferred Guads' suiza to this one because of the generous amount of avocado, but I gotta say I was happy this time around. 

The employees here were friendly and there was lots of seating, though it was busy for lunch. Do note that this location is CASH ONLY and extra orders of chips will cost you $0.65.
author: Camille B.

description:
What can I say about el farolito,
 Mmmmm well this is amazing/greasy mexican food that you pay the price later for having or at least I did.

I finally managed to make it to this place, after everyone talking it up and saying how amazing it is, and I must say it did live up to its expectations.
We ended up getting the super burrito with carne asada and a torta mexicana with al pastor.  If I was to rate this place based on the burrito alone this place would get 5 plus stars, their burritos are everything you wished for and more.  On the flip side, their torta was good but I wasn't blown away, especially from the al pastor, it wasn't very flavorful :/.  
I did see a lot of people ordering tacos and quesadillas, which I will definitely have to try next time.

El farolito I will be back for your burritos!!!
author: Josh Giosue D.

description: It was well worth any wait. They clearly know what they're doing when it comes to delicious food. Flavorful classics and large portions make up for messy tables; their focus is on the food and it shows one way or another. We each tried a burrito and even the regular sizes were too large to finish. Great if you're looking for a vegetarian or vegan option. Still yummy and flavorful despite opting out on the meat.
author: Bethany K.

description:
I'm glad we were hungry at 12:30 am after visiting Twin Peaks, otherwise I would have never found this place! El Farolito is Americanized Mexican food done right, and that is coming from someone who lived in San Diego. 

The store looks like a typical Mexican food hole in the wall. The proportions are a little weird, because it's very narrow with booths lining either side. It's a little dirty...we had to wipe down our table from the previous diners, but it's not awful. 

My bf was peckish, so he just got a taco ($2.50). I was ravenous, so I opted for a Quesadilla Suiza (~$7?), which the cashier helpfully told me was about the size of a burrito. CASH ONLY! We came at a good time, because a wave of customers appeared not 10 minutes after we got there. The taco was decently sized, but...ehh, not worth $2.50. Pretty average. What was amazing though, was my Quesadilla Suiza. It was basically a flatter, crispier burrito. The portion is so large that I had to stop stuffing my face because I was too full. They were not shy with any of the ingredients--every mouthful had juicy al pastor, sour cream, avocados, and cheese. My only regret was that I could not take it home to a fridge...so 1/4 of that beautiful quesadilla was lost :,(. 

I have eaten so much Mexican food, but that Quesadilla Suiza has left quite the impression on me. It is a little more expensive than what I'm used to, but then again it's also San Francisco, so this is probably as cheap as you can get. I would definitely come again. 

Food: 4, Service: 3, Environment: 3, Price: 3
author: Ruth T.

description: A lot of hype for what it is. I came here, got four tacos and a burrito. Made two mistakes - went here for dinner, and didn't get their quesadilla. If you're a visitor from NY or LA, come here after you've done the crawl through Mission.
author: Jeff T.

description: Uhm best late night drunk burritos ever ! Cheap, perfect amount of spicy, and amazing flavor !
author: Lara C.

description: I've lived in The Mission for a few years and this is the best taqueria around. There's always a line and it's cash only, but it's worth the wait
author: Tony P.

description: The over 4000 Yelp reviews brought me to this place.  Having lived in LA, I wasn't that impressed with the food here and still feel Southern California rules supreme for Mexican food.  But they are open late at night, and if you need a taco fix, this might be your place.
author: Laleh J.

description: El Farolito is worth the hype! I came on a weeknight and didn't encounter much of a line. Cash only. The menu offerings are pretty extensive, and aren't just limited to burritos. They offer plates, tacos, tortas, nachos, etc, but I chose to stick with the classic super burrito! I ordered al pastor as my meat. The super burrito came out to almost $10. This is a really, really good burrito. Some of the fillings were not distributed evenly, but everything was so flavorful it didn't impact my experience negatively. The meat itself was tender and there wasn't one piece I had to pick out ... usually I find there are pieces that are overly fatty or tough, but this was high quality meat. The rice was fluffy and well-seasoned, and the pinto beans weren't overly mushy or overly dry. The guac and sour cream seemed to have been plopped down towards the bottom of the burrito, but it was a nice treat once I made my way to that part. The tortilla was a good vehicle for the fillings, but I don't recall it being memorable. I will be back!
author: Terren W.

description:
Classic choice for late night Mexican food in San Francisco. Remember that it's cash only. The place was packed when we went but we were able to get one of the booths (don't expect much cleanliness) and the wait wasn't too bad. 

The burritos are good even for me coming from San Diego. I got the carne asada super burrito ($8). It was packed with rice, beans, tomato, sour cream, and onion. Definitely recommend getting a super burrito over a regular one. The carne asada was good but not the best I've ever had. I thought the al pastor meat that my fiance ordered in his burrito was better.
author: Linda X.

description:
People argue about the best Mission burrito. I only had the chance to try one mission burrito, and Yelp directed me here. 
Jeez, if this isn't the best, I don't know what is. Super fast service and a crazy good burrito. Trust me, people. This is NOT chipotle. 
Plus, it's right next to the BART should you need to pick up some dinner before your flight (insert airplane food joke here.)
author: Surbhi G.

description:
This place isn't 24 hrs like some have said here, but it's hours are long which helps everyone who has a hunger for Mexican food at the most random times of the day.  I usually go here at night, and the lines are indeed long.  The line, however moves quickly so that's not too bad.  Cash only and tables are scarce.  1 star off for the cleanliness of the bathroom.

I went here yesterday morning when it first opened and there was a line, but not as bad as late at night.  I don't know why (maybe the ingredients are fresher in the A.M.), but the super carne asada burrito tasted even better than at night that I wanted to order another for the road.  Customer service is okay and they take orders and make food pretty fast, so no complaints there.  I think I'll take a trip to this place in the morning because what a great way to start your day with a bomb-ass burrito to eat.
author: Chan L.

description: Best late night eat if your in SF. You have to get the super suiza quesadilla it is so yummy!! Especially with their spicy green sauce. On a side note, they run a semi pro soccer team!
author: Ismail S.

description:
The line for this place is INSANE at night, but so worth the food. They've got lots of vegetarian options, but the catch is that it's cash only, so come prepared. The food is cheap and tastes good! 

The sauces are delicious and tasted fresh. I also liked how you could watch the food being made as you are waiting to order. 

Will definitely be back if I'm in the area
author: Jhankhana J.

description:
Legit Mexican food? Most certainly, yes.
"THE BEST BURRITO IN CALIFORNIA"? Eh, no.

I know the folks of SF have a sore spot when you start talking about their burritos so I won't venture too far into that, but as a San Diegan, I can't say this place lives up to *all* of its hype. The food is good, I'll give them that. Tons of cheese, hot meat, grease, etc. But it isn't the best (and definitely not the cheapest) I've had in the state. 

There's probably a line when you arrive, but it's a good opportunity to see the employees hard at work making the food you're about to enjoy. Thank them for it, it looks hot as heck behind those stoves! There are only so many tables in the narrow restaurant so its best not to come in a group any larger than maybe 4 people, but don't let that deter you. If I were in the area and had just finished a long night of drinking, I would definitely not be against coming to this little place to get my grub on.
author: Michelle H.

description: The best burrito in San Francisco. Every bite is amazing. The workers are great, polite and easygoing. I would surely recommend this place to people. Loved I.
author: Valentin E.

description:
Oh man, the food here is GOOD. Everything else isn't.

The food itself gets 5 stars because of how delicious and greasy and AWESOME the burritos and quesadillas are. My go-to is the Carne Asada super burrito, which is less of a food and more of a few bites of HEAVEN. The quesadillas are also super tasty, just be ready for an overload of melted cheese and a healthy dose of calories.

So yeah the food's awesome. However, literally everything else about this establishment drags it down to a 3-star review. It's tiny and get VERY crowded VERY fast. Be ready to wait in line. It's cash only. Be ready to be refused if you only have card. There is never anywhere to sit and the dining tables are always messy. The service is also pretty awful, too, and the workers have bad attitudes when they interact with you. 

Oh well, the food is good so I'm still coming back here.

Tldr; 5-star food + 1-star everything else = 3 stars
author: Phillip V.

description: Yum! So authentic.  I typically don't like US made Mexican fare.  My quesadilla was to die for!
author: Lynn C.

description: Been around this town for a minute (1976). I'm a big fan of Vegetarian burritos done right. Like Azteca on Church St (moved to 16th & Guerrero now gone). El Farolito on 24th has been a decent place for years-good people, but they're treating Vegetarian burritos like a joke now and it's getting worse. Slam two cups of cooked rice on a big ass tortilla, a teaspoon of beans and done. I'd give them 2 stars except they feed a lot of people and are open until 2:30.
author: Richard H.

description:
Tried the carne asada regular burrito. Wasn't hungry enough for what awesomeness the super burrito might have been, but was glad to see it has avocado in it.

Solid all-around on flavor, size, and price. Per the recommendation of another customer, I tried a bunch of the salsas and enjoyed the salsa verde (which I was told has avocado in it?!). I'm definitely coming back to try some of their other options.

PS. I've been to nearby competitor La Tacqueria - El Farolito wins in my books.
author: Cindy S.

description: Their super burrito is no joke. Loved the feel of the place and I can tell that it's even better when you're not sober. The salsas are good and for the price it works.
author: Andrew T.

description: Our most recent trip to the Bay Area we engaged in a burrito showdown between El Farolito and La Taqueria, and the verdict went to La Taqueria. The biggest difference between El Farolito and La Taqueria is the portion size, which is basically taken up by rice in the giant El Farolito burritos. Still a damn good burrito, and cheaper than La Taqueria down the street too, so if I were really hangry I would go for an El Farolito burrito in a heartbeat. Lengua burrito is suuper tender and flavorful--highly recommend it. And if the burrito alone isn't enough to fill you up, you get chips and an array of tasty salsas to go with your burrito monstrosity!
author: Jessica H.

description: Came to San Francisco for vacation and stopped by this place....there's a big line to wait in, but defenitely worth the wait =)
author: Grios24 R.

description:
CASH ONLY

I MUST try their burritos the next time I come here. Third time is the charm! 

I realized I am no longer basic when it comes to tacos. Al pastor cannot satisfy me as much as it used to.  I am all about their cabeza and lengua tacos. BOMB.COM.  Next time, I'll try out their other exotic ones such as intestines possibly!

Their space is definitely not as big as La Taqueria, which I cannot get myself to get in line for that one still. You know what they all say, a dirty and divey space means more authentic and legic mexican food you will GET!
author: Kathy D.

description:
Five words. Lengua and Shrimp Super Burrito. That's it. That's all you need. 

The burritos here will literally revive you after drinking downtown at the bars. Just kidding, not literally, but it does the trick. Get here before 2am, and the line is manageable. Get here at or after 2am, and expect to wait 30 minutes or more for your food. 

The concept is simple. Wait in line and usually one of the guys that work here will make his way down the line and take your order. He'll give you a ticket with your food order and you pay at the register and wait on the side. 

The shrimp burrito is delicious already on its own. They have large chunks, and I mean CHUNKS of shrimp in it. And if you add lengua to it, it is elevated to a whole 'nother tenderness and flavor level. On top of that, the super burrito usually comes with avocado and sour cream. I MEAN COME ON. 

Tortilla chips are 65 cents a bag and there's unlimited pico de gallo and tomatillo salsa. Those are usually my favorite. But the pico de gallo here is spicier than usual, but medium at most. 

There is a reason why the line here is usually out the door because it's the perfect way to end a great night. The worst part of this place is they only accept cash. There is however a convenient but annoying ATM outside, so I do recommend coming a little prepared and bringing some cash.
author: Nancy L.

description:
Food: 4.5/5.0
Service: 2.0/5.0
Value: 3.5/5.0
Decor: 1.5/5.0
Overall: 4.0/5.0 

Oh, El Farolito.  How have I never written a review for you yet.  If anyone's wondering what my favorite spot on Mission is, take a wild guess.  If you're thinking to yourself that this is ridiculous and ___ is better, then you a) eh, could be right and b) need to go back into your corner.

Mexican coke and a carne asada superburrito is my go-to 1-2 punch for a food coma.  Go at lunch.  Go again for dinner.  Go a last time before they close.  And enjoy.
author: Damian W.

description:
Very crowded on a Friday night but so worth it ! 

Ordered the Steak Quesadilla and my oh my.. That thing was oooooozing with cheese ! Love it !! And they don't go cheap with the meat either ! 
Orgasmic ! In love !! :D yummy !!!! 

Chips were kinda stale though.. Really stale actually but the quesadilla made up for it :).
author: Jenny N.

description: Has anyone ordered the cabeza here? I ordered the cabeza taco and the cashier charged me extra - even though the sign only said that lengua is charged extra. The food is ok... don't like the idea of being ripped off
author: Eddie J.

description: Best burrito in SF. It's cheap, filling and tastes amazing.
author: Dora S.

description:
Cash only
Amazing food
Great taqueros!!
Open REALLY late
Long lines(for obvious reasons)
Worth the time and money
author: Jose D.

description:
CASH ONLY!!! There's an ATM right outside if you don't have cash and don't mind paying the convenience fee.

My friends and I came here at around 1:30am on a Friday night and the line was VERY long (not a surprise, very expected). We were hesitant to wait in line at first, but the food made it worth it. THE FOOD WAS AMAZING.

We got 5 tacos: 2 carnitas and 3 chicken. We wanted carne asada tacos, but they ran out of carne asada by the time we got to the register to order. The tacos were fantastic. They were cheap and packed with so much meat! Great value. I can't wait to come back to try their burritos. Also, there aren't too many tables and the place is packed so I would recommend getting the food to-go.

PS: do NOT use their bathrooms...very disgusting.

And yes, the line is WORTH IT!!!!!
author: Jen S.

description: It's not the cleanest and they only accept cash, but the food is delicious and very filling. I love their salsas and that chips are only $0.65! Also great that they have vegetarian options. It was worth waiting in line for on the street, with interesting "street neighbors" wandering around.
author: Jenine G.

description:
I was starving and this place is open much later than all the food places near SOMA on a weekday, so I had to come try this place out especially since it is located right next to bart.

My friend recommend the super quesadilla with the green sauce and I have to say that I loved it! The sheer size of the quesadilla was impressive and the green sauce was sooooo addicting. Looks like I've found my new favorite super quesadilla!
author: Edward W.

description: We came here for an authentic West Coast burrito, and this well-trafficked dive in the Mission District delivered. I had the generously-portioned super burrito with lengua. If I had it to do over again, I would order a regular burrito with a meat more familiar to my untrained palate. What I ordered could easily be split, and then you'd have room for something else or just be comfortably full.
author: David L.

description:
Hands down the best burrito of my pathetic little life. I think I may have ascended into a higher level of existence upon the first bite of the super-sized carne asada burrito.

The burrito was wrapped nice and firmly so I had no problems keeping it together. The blend of meat, rice, beans, and whole avocado slices was heavenly and perfectly flavored. Sometimes when I eat at Chipotle, the steak is a little tough in comparison to the rest of the burrito. Not here. The carne asada was the most tender I've ever had and spectacularly seasoned. They were very generous with the avocado and the proportions of all the ingredients must have approached the Golden Ratio. 

The available salsas are similarly amazing. I recommend the green. 

If I ever visit SF again, I will definitely hit this place up.
author: William M.

description: The only good part about farolito is that they serve tacos pretty late, but as far as it being open late... there is nothing special about there tacos. They are a little over priced and oversized. They do have fast service and they add chips to your order which is appreciated. I probably won't visit again because I've found much better tacos in the Bay Area.
author: Edi G.

description: We ordered the Super Shrimp Burrito and boy was it amazing! We have eaten at several high end restaurants during our trip to SF however all we can keep remembering is the large shrimp and great flavor of our shrimp  burritos.
author: Dani J.

description:
It's always hard for me to review a burrito place because well... I don't like burritos. The SO insisted on coming here so I could try the best burrito in America. Spoiler alert: if you don't like burritos, this place isn't going to change your perspective on that. However, what I can appreciate is cheap delicious Mexican food. 

We came on a Saturday night around dinner time. There was a small line outside the door. I think we queued maybe for 15 minutes which wasn't too bad. There's some seating inside but there isn't a ton. I think the more popular move is to just get it to go and then sit in Dolores and enjoy the quintessential SF moment. 

We got the classic burrito, a quesadilla, and some chips. While I thought the burrito was pretty good... like I said, I'm not a big burrito lover. I was, however, thoroughly pleased and impressed with the quesadilla. It was freaking delicious, the portion was huge, and I think it literally cost $2. What a steal. I'd come back for the quesadilla alone.

Overall, good Mexican place with giant portions at a cheap price. Will prob be back to try tacos next time because I actually like tacos.
author: Jasmine X.

description: As a Seattleite, I'm always amazed by the Mexican food in California, and I was blown away by my late lunch at El Farolito. I ordered three tacos (al pastor, carnitas, and chorizo) and found all three to be incredibly greasy but also packed with flavor and juicy as hell. I walked out completely filled and very happy. I'll be returning before I head back.
author: Andrew T.

description: This place has a very old-school authentic feel. Very much a no-frills establishment. That being said the prices seem pretty affordable and note that it is cash only. My order was ready in just a couple of minutes and I was able to get a vegan burrito which was called the veggie burrito regular. It was absolutely delicious because the rice is cooked perfectly, everything was hot and they had amazing green salsa. That being said most of the burrito was rice. There was also supposed to be avocado salsa and tomato but I found very little of that in there.
author: Marisa L.

description:
Delicious burrito! 

One of the best I've tried here in sf.
Very good delicious burrito has all of the works.
The salsa is very delicious 
The burrito is a pretty large size as well
I will be returning for another burrito the chips and salsa were also very enjoyable and a selection of drinks 
Are also available there's a place to sit and guess what it s a very good place to eat
author: Cecilia H.

description:
This is a grown mans burrito, take your diet elsewhere. The Carne asada is ginormous, generous portions of meat grilled to perfection, but of course you know that as it has been well publicized by previous yelpers. The menu is fill with authentic Mexican classics. These guys have mastered thier craft. just A couple additional talking points:

1. The word sketchy has been thrown around. I know sketchy, never stopped me from venturing out, as I tend to judge solely based on food(or at least heavily). With that being said, sketchy would be appropriate! Sketchy in every sense, both inside and the entire area out. 
2. Being that El farolito is the stuff of legends, I am proud to say that I feel there are some burritos in the Boston area that can stand up to this west coast giant.
author: Donald S.

description: Came here after viewing an episodes of Munchies. I'm from LA and made it a point to go here because of the review that it was the best. WOW....Wrong the burrito just was packed with tasteless rice and beans with three shrimps inside and a somewhat sort of avocado. My family and I opened these burritos up with high hopes and were disappointed. Not worth it at all price was crazy at almost 15 bucks a pop.
author: Patricia C.

description:
Super casual place with amazing authentic Mexican food.

The quesadilla was out of this world and the tacos were good as well- definitely a little spicy. There was a line when we got there but it was well worth it.
author: Gina M.

description:
one of the better mexican places in town. 

of course it pales in comparison to anything in chula vista or across the border (which isn't too far btw) but it's great 

i love the people who own this place and their service is great!!!
author: Fat Panda X.

description: One of the best places in this city, very tasty and large burritos, that will not leave you hungry. Great homemade salsa. I highly recommend this place to stop on your burrito journey.
author: Grey W.

description: No consistency. Sometimes it fucking amazing, other times it's some soggy shit. I'm referring to the burrito. Also fix the fucking atm outside.
author: Abdul C.

description:
Honestly, this might be my favourite burrito spot. It's probably a good thing it's a little bit of a walk from my apartment, otherwise I would 100% eat here too often.

It's a classic mission burrito atmosphere inside. A decent amount of seating inside, but late at night on the weekends it definitely gets packed. The first time I ever came here, there was a lineup that swung around the front of the building outside!

I almost always get the super burrito, and haven't had a complaint about any of the meat choices I've put inside. You can watch the whole burrito making from the line, like many other burrito joints. Definitely great taste and value, and can't recommend it highly enough.
author: Rajeev S.

description: On a quick weekend trip to San Francisco I estimated that I had time for one burrito so the question became which one? El Farolito seemed to be a consistent favorite so off I went. There was no line around 12:15 on a Friday which was a pleasant surprise. I ordered a carne asada super burrito with everything on it to go. It took about 10 minutes during which I snagged some of that fire avocado salsa. Carne asada was super flavorful and moist and the rest of the ingredients had a nice balance. Be prepared to be very full at the end of the burrito but it's worth every bite.
author: Alexandra K.

description:
Dang, El Farolito. You ruined, yet saved me, all at the same time. 

Heading back to BART at midnight, tipsy and hungry, El Farolito is truly that beacon of light*. The lines are long, but they move fast and for $12 I got stale chips and salsa, a beer and the biggest, most delicious quesadilla suiza filled with chorizo, avocado and cheese. I inhaled this beast with so.much.delight. I didn't share, I didn't make eye contact, I didn't speak, I don't think I took a breath. I just sat and ate and enjoyed every greasy bite.

In and out in about 20 minutes and for $12 I ate enough for three. The burritos are behemoth status, but I prefer the quesadilla that focuses on the delicious meat and cheese vs the fillers of rice and beans.

It gets crowded, but man, that midnight feast saved me from a crazy hangover, but I went to bed with calorie remorse and I woke up thirsty as a mo'fo and with some even more serious calorie regret. Womp womp.

Leave the diet at home and enjoy this greasy, gluttonous Mexican legend.

* - El Farolito means lighthouse in Spanish!
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I came here in hopes of a good taco and the reviews said this was the place. Surely enough the reviews were off or maybe this is what a good taco place is for the locals of San Francisco. I really wanted it to be good! Unfortunately the Asada meat was dry and the tortilla was hard. El pastor was also dry and over cooked. Suiza quesadilla was nothing special. The burrito was huge but what's the point when the meat is over cooked. I know I can eat but eating is my hobby lol I should have known when I tried the horchata because it was awful but I had hopes because I really love tacos ! Being an Angelino it's safe to say the tacos and burritos and horchata are definitely a Los Angeles specialty!!
author: Carol F.

description:
Big burritos. Long lines.
If you're hungry and are in the neighborhood grab your cash and try this place out, but be prepared to wait. I've been here a couple times now, mostly on my way to Bart, and the burritos do not disappoint, even after a ride in my backpack to East Bay. Steak is my meat of choice in the super burrito. I can never finish one of those super burritos though. You could probably cut one in half to share and still be satisfied.
If you aren't looking to grab the food and go there are tables, but it's a pretty crowded restaurant.
author: Audrey D.

description:
This is my favorite burrito place in the entire San Francisco Bay area. They're open late, there are a few locations and I believe the mission location is the best one. For the more adventurous sorts, or those in the know Lengua it delightful and tender. 

if you don't know what language is, order it and eat it and then wait an hour before looking it up online to find out what it is. For the less adventurous people, order tacos Al Pastore or the super burrito Al Pastore
author: Lucas W.

description:
After all the good things I've heard about this place (and the 4,000+ reviews!), I was a little underwhelmed to be honest. El Farolito hits all the right notes when it comes to flavor combinations, but something was lacking when it came to the carne asada .. lack of seasoning? We got a carne asada super burrito, an al pastor taco, and a lengua taco. My husband said that the burrito reminded him of El Gordo's in Berkeley, and I liked the burrito overall, but we both thought the carne asada could have been more flavorful. To be honest, I liked the California burrito at Viva Taqueria in Santa Clara better. We liked the al pastor, which wasn't too greasy and had a good kick to it. The lengua could have been better; like the carne asada, if just wasn't very flavorful.

If this is the best that the Bay Area has to offer, then this just cements my belief that the best Mexican food remains closer to the border in LA and San Diego.
author: Rachel L.

description: Super Quesadilla Suiza all day everyday! It's THE thing to get here in my opinion. To be fair, I haven't tried much else from here but if your not in the mood for tacos or a burrito, try the SQS. 4/5
author: Jon E.

description:
Beef Tongue anything. Burrito, taco, plate -  just get beef tongue as your protein choice. It's rare to find a taco/burrito joint that serves beef tongue and El Farolito cooks it superbly. 

Did I say get the beef tongue here? 

Eat here. Bomb Mexican food for your buck.
author: Janice K.

description:
I come from a small town that thinks its burritos are the greatest in the world. I subscribed to that belief for a really long time, too. Been all around California, and no burritos came close. Until, of course, this place came into my life.

I can't believe how good their burritos are. I can't attest to anything else on the menu because I just can't bring myself to get anything else. The meat is always cooked perfectly; tortillas are the perfect texture and taste great; the flavors all come together wonderfully. It's like a symphony of flavor every time. I can't get enough. Not to mention their salsa verde is always perfect. Just like the rest of this place.
author: Kollin M.

description: The burrito here is definitely massive! It's so good though and you just can't resist takin another bite, even if you are completely full! Got their super burrito and it was loaded with steak, cheese, sour cream, pico and avocado. Loved the grilled steak and was loaded with so much flavor!!!
author: Blu M.

description: They made the wrong burrito with no refried beans. Then they threw some refried beans in. This is how it came back to us. And they wouldn't make a new one. I know it's busy at night but at least make a new burrito that will not cost you much to make
author: Nathalie H.

description: SO good oh my gosh!! We got a super burrito, and it was perfect.  The tortilla is nice and chewy, there's a chili relleno inside the burrito mixed with cheese, avocado, beans, and rice.  We got it with chicken and it was amazing.  Definitely would go back for more!
author: Nina L.

description: The best chicken burrito I have had in San Francisco - maybe ever? I also tried a small chicken taco and it was very good! Terrific value and they offer steep discounts on Restaurant.com.
author: Charmaine L.

description:
Now THIS is the best burrito in San Francisco, burrito bracket be damned!

I came here after a long flight from New York, that Mexican food wasteland. The moment I landed I knew I had to come here to get my carne asada fix.

Mind you, I can usually finish a burrito no problemo. But this time around, about 75% of the way through I was defeated by deliciousness. It was just so amazing I couldn't handle it! The meat was seasoned to perfection. The beans were outta control. And the tortilla? DOPE.
author: Sarah G.

description: Good el pastor super burrito. Although it was way too SPACY and it did not say it anywhere in the menu. I almost could not eat it.
author: Andrea E.

description: Came in on a Sunday at 2 PM, there was still a line outside the door. The line moved pretty quickly though, you could watch them cook while you wait and line and consider the menu. The inside is small and cramped but it's whatever. I got a super burrito with chorizo, the burrito was fat and stuffed with plenty of filling. The flavors of the burrito were balanced really well with the chorizo not being too overpowering. I also got some chips and some salsa. There's a sign that says salsa is $3.75/cup but everyone was just taking it so it's whatever.
author: Donald C.

description:
Surprisingly, I tried El Farolito for the first time a few years back and didn't even realize it was such a hyped up establishment. It's one of the many taquerias in Mission, but just so happens to be at a busy intersection so that's where I ended up. 

Food here is beyond delicious and there's almost always a line out the door whenever I stop by. Somehow those long lines always move very fast so you're in and out of there in no time. I mainly get a carne asada super burrito, but have tried the suiza since that's what everybody raves about. Regardless of what you get, you'll be satisfied. The prices are pretty standard within Mission (around $8 for a burrito), but it's cash only!
author: Catherine L.

description:
YOU SLAY ME EL FAROLITO. YOU SLAY ME SO HARD.

This was a RELIGIOUS EXPERIENCE. I have LITERALLY never wanted dead animals in my body as badly as I wanted them when I visited El Farolito.

Their salsa brings men to their knees. Their hot sauce is what Beyonce carries in her bag. Their carne asada are what people skip sex for. Their tacos smell like the rainbows bursting out of a unicorn's butt. Their chips taste like food after you've starved for 3 days straight. The whole experience is 100% unparalleled. 

I seriously recommend you get THREE TACOS, each with either Carne Asada or Carnitas. Then, get the chips that cost 65 cents.

Put a $10 bill down and treat yourself to an experience that can only be rivaled by the soft, luxurious feel of cashmere. To be honest, you don't even need $10 to get a proper heap of food here.

El Farolito can basically be likened to a Beyonce concert. It's explosive, it's worth it, and it is STRAIGHT UP LETHAL.

To be honest, I usually don't write with all caps or any sort of exaggerated, dramatic passion. But goddamn, El Farolito. You did me dead. U DO ME DEAD.

Lol screw you Yelp, this place serves 100 stars.
author: Anders Z.

description:
Finally got to try the legendary El Farolito and went back multiple times in quick succession. I have had friends rave about this place for years and I understand why. This is a tiny hole in the wall which serves extremely good comfort food. The food and place are not for the faint of heart.

I was told that the item to get was the super suiza avocado steak and it did not disappoint. It is super rich, filling and yummy. It should really be 2 meals but I ate it all in one sitting. I was a sloth for the rest of the day but it was worth it. On subsequent trips, I tried other items like the chicken flats and the flan. The super suiza is my favorite and the bomb.
author: Sunil R.

description:
The carne asada suiza quesadilla with spinach tortilla. SO BOMB. Instead of cutting it like a pizza, they roll it up like a burrito. It's basically a burrito-quesadilla hybrid.

This is a great example of a quesadilla done perfectly right. The crunch of the tortilla and mouth-watering interior totally satisfied my taste buds. The quesadilla is so packed with flavor that you can't help but chow it down.

Definitely coming back!
author: Jenny H.

description: The legendary El Farolito.  Need I say more?  So good.  So much food.  So cheap.  So quick.
author: Andrew P.

description: Way better than taqueria Cancun! Had this for the first time last night and it was absolutely delicious. Vegetarian burrito and quesadillas with salsa verde! Yum
author: Suprita K.

description: Both my friend and I are new to SF and had heard about the infamous "best burrito" war between La Taqueria and this place, so we decided to give it a go during our lunch break. We came at 10:30AM on a weekday so there was no line and got two massive carne asada super burritos for about 8 bucks each. You could definitely make two meals out of it. The burrito was super delicious and filling. Probably one of the best affordable meals you can get in SF.
author: Saundra N.

description:
WOW! As tourists from Texas looking for "The Best Burrito in the Bay Area" I think we may have found it here at El Farolito! There are a few Mission District area institutions that get high marks, but this is the one that is open very late! Don't let the outside appearance or rampant homeless people on drugs scare you away... the food in here is legit! 

We had a Super Burrito with Steak... and for the size, price and flavor I would have to give this my "Jared Award" for the best burrito I have ever had. Yep. It was to die for. I washed it down with a Mexican lime soda in a glass bottle and had a chicken taco just got good measure. 

My wife and I were easily able to split the burrito, making this meal among the cheapest we had in our San Fransisco visit. 

The place was small, cramped, a little messy and sketchy as hell from the street... but inside it was nothing but pure burrito bliss. This is coming from a Texan. Absolutely legit, do not come here without eating a burrito. And by "here" I don't mean the Mission District, I mean the bay area of California. Happy Eating!!!
author: Jared G.

description:
Came here for a late night run.  

Ordered carne asada quesadilla para dos and a shrimp super taco.  Total came to 18 and some change.  A ton of food for less than 20 bucks.  Me and my future baby daddy finished the taco and one quesadilla, saved the other quesadilla for tomorrow's lunch.  The ingredients tasted very fresh.  Took away a star because they don't have salt and pepper at the tables or the salsa bar(quesadilla wasn't salty enough but was still good) and their hot sauces/salsas are below average.  If they had one good salsa, this place is 5 stars.
author: Yuhan Z.

description: I'm not sure why this place is so hyped. The food if just about okay (Full disclosure - I'm a vegetarian so my perspective is limited). And the chips - I honestly think Chipotle chips are a lot better.
author: H P.

description:
I've had a back log of places I wanted to write Yelp reviews for, and El Farolito is SO good it motivated me to start them. 

The super burrito (I opted for half al pastor/half carne asada) is amazing. I've made it my mission to try as burritos this summer as possible, and this is definitely the best one so far. The meat is so tasty and all of the other ingredients are well-balanced. Also the burrito is as big as my arm and $8 (less than that if you don't want it super...but you do, trust me.) A lot of other places seem cheaper, but then charge you a lot to make it whatever their version of super and also sometimes charge you to split your meat options, but I really can't believe the value of this thing. I got it and brought it home thinking I'd just eat half, but before I knew what was happening it was all gone.

I've also tried cabeza, chorizo and al pastor tacos (good size, lots of meat, tasty) and the quesadilla suiza (which I got with Al Pastor and split with my fiance...we definitely ended up with a normal whole quesadilla's worth each.) Quesadilla was super yummy and melty and awesome. Fell apart as I ate it. And another amazing value.

Yummy yummy hole in the wall, I've been here three times in the past week, no shame. The entrance smells a bit like urine and the line is ridiculous at seemingly all hours, but they're quick and it is worth the wait.

Oh, but don't use the bathroom there.
author: Christine U.

description:
Where else can you get an overwhelming large burrito at 1am on a Sunday for $8? Nowhere else in this goddamm city, that's what. God bless Farolito and what they provide. 

Some people order things beside the super burrito and I really don't understand what's wrong with them. Just get it with carne asada or carnitas and let the good times roll.
author: Brady S.

description:
This was so good, I went multiple times in a 3-day period. Located right outside the 24th Street BART station, El Farolito isn't the nicest or cleanest place you've eaten at. However, what they lack in flash, they more than make up for in the food. Also, you feel good knowing that both locals and tourists come here and that even though the decor is old, it has stood the test of time. I can't speak for authenticity, but I can speak for tastiness.

Must-get: Super burritos and quesadillas. The tacos here are delicious too, but I would say go for the burritos and quesadillas. Regardless, they really load on the cheeses, meats and other toppings, and the burritos can really last you a couple meals. The super quesadilla para dos will feed you and another person for more than two meals. They use lard in a lot of stuff, which makes the taste super rich, but beware for all you vegetarians/vegans out there. My favorites are the lengua (beef tongue), carne asada, and carnitas. Yeah, that's basically the whole menu, but damn, is it good. Beats the chain burrito places ANY DAY.

Service can be a little spotty when it comes to fulfilling your order, but nothing really unexpected from a super busy Mission burrito bar. Prices are great, portions are again, huge, and you can go nuts with the avocado and salsa bar, located right next to the cash register. Great for late nights and just overall Mexican cravings. Cash only.
author: Eric J.

description: One of the best taquerias in the mission, very delicious and huge burritos that won't leave you feeling ill post eat. Good homemade salsas. Bathroom looks a bit like a murder scene which is par for the course. Highly recommend this place for a stop in your tour of mission burritos.
author: Dennis B.

description: Heard someone on line telling their friend that this is the best burrito you'll ever have. It's not an exaggeration. There is always a bit of a line here because it's that good. First time I came, I had the Super Shrimp Burrito. I thought I wasn't that hungry but ended up scarfing down the whole thing because it was so delicious. I have also had the Quesadilla Super Suiza here and it was comparable to, almost better than, the burrito. Pretty good range of prices too.
author: Ruby H.

description: Best burrito in SF by far. I hate that it is getting more well known and the prices are being raised, but I always try to stop by when I am in the neighborhood
author: Jake H.

description: Their burritos are  HUGE! I came here doing a mission taco crawl with some friends. Deifnitely tasty but I prefer la taqueria
author: Jasper L.

description: I love this place. I was first introduced to this place back in high school. I've tried many other burritos, tacos and nachos but I seem to come back to this place all the time. The staff are friendly, the place gets really packed. I will definitely order to go. Cash only. The sauce bar is nice. I usually just take the water cup and mis my own sauces together.
author: Bonnie C.

description: Super fresh and yummy food. They are always busy but they are nice and prompt. Generous with the meat and flavorful.
author: Betsy G.

description:
Guys. Burritos from El farolito are SO good, I witnessed a homeless man spend his LAST/ONLY $10 on a burrito here. 

And I would agree. And also, I should have had a bigger heart and bought his damn burrito, but my thinking is not always fast enough. Anyway, back to the burrito at hand. 

This is the one you want. In your hand, and in your belly. Mostly in your mouth, though. I got the super with pastor, and it was HUGE AND DELICIOUS. (Yes. We're still talking about a burrito, okay?) it was perfection. I skipped the sour cream, cause that's my thing, and I don't think I missed out. 

Also, don't forget the salsa. Don't forget the salsa! Don't. And when you get it, don't forget to eat it with your burrito. The green was awesome, but the red made my taste buds scream out in ecstasy... The red one in the middle, when I was there. So fresh. So juicy. So filled with flavor. 

Also, much as I love avocado, I would have enjoyed it more without. Weird, and I can't explain it. But damn, this burrito is the one I want to stay with me forever. I mean, until I order another one.
author: Tina S.

description:
I went back and tried the steak super burrito. Again, a massive serving that's best shared unless you're a big eater. But I have to say that this was a much better burrito than my first one (even before a night of drinking lol).

This place is always packed but line moves fast and service is friendly. I would recommend to anyone wanting a Mission burrito.
author: Sue V.

description:
When I was planning a trip to SF I knew I had to hit up at least one place to get an authentic Mission burrito. Someone told me they were the inspiration behind Chipotle and other type of fast casual burrito joints, but that these burritos were even bigger and tastier at around the same price. You don't need to tell me twice...I'm always down for cheap and delicious Mexican food.

When we pulled up, we saw the line was out the door. Luckily it moved pretty quick. They got the process down and operated like a well oiled machine. While in line you could see all the guys assembling everything. They were like masters of their craft as they scooped out perfect slices of avocado within seconds. 

At first we were worried that we wouldn't get seats since the place wasn't that big and there were a ton of people there. There was even a random mariachi band playing music in between the booths and made it seem even more crowded. Maybe it was because everyone was getting their orders to go but somehow it cleared up by the time we placed our order and we had no problem snagging a booth.  

I was super hungry and went with the asada super burrito and the asada quesadilla. Realistically half of the burrito would've been enough to satisfy me, but since I was on vacation I decided to just power through it all. I thought it was awesome that they just had a self service salsa bar where you can just grab whatever you want. The burrito was huge as expected and packed to the max with meat. At Chipotle I watch the workers be all stingy while scooping the meat. Nope, not here. That thing was just filled with juicy, delicious pieces of steak. It was just a solid burrito all around and all the components tasted great together. 

The quesadilla also tasted pretty good. Even though I ordered asada in both the burrito and quesadilla, the quesadilla steak was actually prepared in a slightly different way. Instead of little pieces of meat, they put thin slices of the steak in it and I actually liked it better this way. They also put enough cheese in there to make me question whether I was lactose haha. Both the burrito and quesadilla were sittin heavy in my stomach. 

Overall, everything was solid. There weren't too many surprises from a taste standpoint, just some tasty Mexican food with generous portions and good value. Cash only.
author: Mike M.

description: Good spot to grab a burrito late night in the mission.  Been there for a long time too.   Not the cleanest of places but a good burrito to say the least.
author: Mark P.

description: The best burrito I've had to date. Crispy pork, super flavorful, and perfectly proportioned. They have burritos down to a fine art! If you are looking for a delicious and quick lunch and are willing to sacrifice ambiance and a couple minutes to wait in line, you will not be disappointed!
author: Nicole C.

description:
This was the best burrito I have ever had. I got a carne asada super burrito and it was spectacular. It looks like a burrito you'd get at Chipotle, but it's so much better. It was also really cheap, something like $8 for a burrito that seemed to weigh 3 lbs.

Carne asada, rice, beans, tomato, cilantro, onion, cheese, sour cream, and guacamole all get wrapped up in a gigantic flour tortilla and wrapped in foil for structural support. Best way to eat it? I'd say with your hands, unwrapping each section as you make your way down. The salsa here is great too, make sure to add some to the burrito between bites.

It'd be over if they had late night drunken burrito places this good in NYC.
author: Nick C.

description:
This was our first stop here in San Fran because the bf was craving Mexican. The line was long but it moved rather quickly. Word to the wise: The neighborhood is a bit sketch looking. Now for the food: 

the quesadilla super suiza (cheese, steak, fresh guac, sour cream, pico de gallo). I probably had hungry eyes cuz I saw them making it while I was standing in line and I knew I had to have one. But it's not that good. Just standard asada quesadilla. 

Carne asada/adobada mix super burrito was good. I got no beans tho. Rice, sour cream, beef, pork, guac, pico de gallo. It was the perfect combination of flavors. The rice was really tasty. Not too salty and rather creamy. Some pieces of the adobada was very tough tho.
author: Grace L.

description: My boyfriend recently had a burrito from this location and it gave him food poisoning for the next 2 days! This is not the cleanest place, so customers beware! I'm not sure if they wash their hands before making the meals or if they don't properly wash their meats or cook ware. We've been going to the Grand Ave location for years and have never had food poisoning. But this location gave us food poisoning after the first time! So disappointing.
author: Somali P.

description:
El farolito, one of the best damn mission burritos you're ever going to get. I got the carne asada super burrito. It's a super burrito for a reason, its super big and super tasty and it;s a super value. The thing is like the size of my arm. Trust me, its legit tasty and legit awesome. The biggest downside is there are no seats most of the time and that the line is usually very long.

Overall, a burrito worth waiting for especially for its nice price. Go with the super burrito, no regrets on that one.
author: Raymond H.

description:
Consistently delivering delicious tacos/burritos/quesadillas to the drunks at 2AM and the sobers at 2PM out of an un-gentrified hole-in-the-wall establishment at un-gentrified costs. I'm looking at you, $4 toast.

Pros:
+ Open late
+ Tastes great
+ Line moves fast

Cons:
- Sanitary questions but it's 2AM so...whatevs

Recommendations:
+ Burritos and quesadillas all day!

I came here last night after a year long hiatus. Still delivering the same delicious late night eats. Some transient-looking man and woman were both giving the security a hard time. Had a hard time walking out since they kind of blocked my way, but an even harder time watching idiotic folks give others who are trying to make an honest living a hard time at 2AM. What is wrong with this world? 2AM questions and feels.

Don't ever change, El Farolito! We natives love you to death, at 2AM and at 2PM!
author: Fanny W.

description:
Another tasty burrito at el farolito.  I had beef tongue and my wife had shredded chicken.  I'm not sure these are so remarkable that they are worthy traveling great distances for.  There is another location a few blocks east and another location in Oakland that seem to have the same menu.  After eating at the flagship location, which was pretty packed, we walked past the other mission location, and there were plenty of free tables.  Lesson learned.  

The lengua was good, with a rich beefy taste.  The shredded chicken was unremarkable.  There is also a grilled chicken option, and that might be better.  

I didn't actually see a true al pastor spit behind the counter, and that makes me suspect it is not the genuine article.  Going forward, I think I might seek out tacos instead of burritos.  And I might try some of the other meats (brains, cabeza).
author: Delaware F.

description: Awesome burritos and tacos.  Very good for a late night meal in the city.  Keep up the great work.
author: L J.

description:
This place has a line all day long!  It's a hole in the wall place, but the food is very good.  Ordered two burritos for $16 together.  The service is quick and the price point is very appealing. I will definitely be back!  I'll never go back to Pancho Villa!

Seating is scarce and is on a first come basis, but the turnaround is so quick, you will not have to wait long.

Oh yes, don't forget.  CASH ONLY.
author: R M.

description: Had to check out this place, seeing how it has so many reviews. One of my friends got the super burrito and I opted for the two quesadillas with carne asada. The burritos and the quesadillas were massive. I thought they were very well executed. My friend who likes spicy was sorted of disappointed at the three salsas available. The quesadillas definitely filled me up and I definitely can see how this would be a great place to go after you've had some beers. Wish they didn't only take cash but business is booming. Seating is very limited. Solid meal.
author: Daniel C.

description:
I thought that this place was okay. I ordered a carne Assad super burrito. The meat was cooked well but it wasn't very flavorful, I had to dose my burrito in salsa in order to enjoy it. There was ample cheese, avocado and beans but the meat wasn't very well seasoned. The ambience of the place wasn't ideal. It wasn't he a super clean place and there was a random guy in the back corner talking to himself which sort of distracted from the experience. 

Overall, it was a fine meal but I probably wouldn't go back.
author: Alexandra W.

description: I've eaten alot of Mexican food places (Sacramento, Stockton, San Jose etc) but this by far, when it comes to burritos, is the best burrito I have ever eaten.
author: Hao H.

description:
Hmmm I don't know I think it's just okay.  

I went with the burrito of course (not the super) since I don't really care for avocado.  Went with the carne asada as my protein.  Carne asada was pretty flavorfu but not the best.  The salsa verde is definitely the way to go out of the two salsas there.  Portions wise, wow, this thing is a beast.  We ordered 2 burritos and damn bag was heavy.

I tried a bit of the Super Burrito which has a bunch more stuff like avocado and sour cream, then I get the hype.  For avocado lovers, this burrito, which is heavy as hell too, is probably the most perfect burrito.  Just, it's not for me.

The Suiza Quesedillas was the surprise for me though.  Never had it before and the marinated steak with the cheese was pretty damn awesome.  The quesedillas was just normal size which was a bummer cause I could probably eat two orders of it.

The line is also very long if you go late at night.  Drunk crowd galore.
author: Duke C.

description: I went on a mission. A mission far. A mission alito. A farrolito in the mission. I come here every single time I come to SF. Once I came here, a customer got really mad at me for getting in her way, and poured a cup of salsa on me. Did I leave? Hell no. Did I wait for my burrito with salsa over some of my clothes and hair? You bet. The revolution is not a dinner party. And in this case specifically the revolution was dinner, but it was still not a party. Well it was kind of a party, in my mouth. Because this super burrito is like the best burrito - the main part is the meat is perfect and it's slathered with sour cream. They also offer whole wheat tortillas. Go to the mission. Go do the mission. You mission is to get an el farrolito burrito.
author: Willy X.

description:
I ordered 3 soft tacos: lingua, cabeza, and tripas. 

I've had very positive experiences in the past with the quesadilla and burritos but the tacos were dry and the meat was overcooked this time.
author: Wendi A.

description: The best spot in the mission la taq has fallen off giving tiny burritos to tourists claiming to be the best. El farolito hasn't changed at all in a neighborhood trying to cling to its identity.
author: Matt C.

description:
I took one star off because this spot is cash only. Once it was our turn to order, we noticed the cash only sign on the register and had to walk to the closest BOA. Not cool.

I ordered a shredded chicken super burrito with no rice.  The super burrito included: meat, rice, beans (pinto, black, refried), salsa, cheese, sour cream, and avocado (fresh- not watered down guac). Even with no rice, my burrito was as large as my boyfriend's burrito. The chicken was all white meat and juicy. Because I chose shredded chicken, my burrito was a little on the soupy side.
